titleStmt.title: The tenth muse lately sprung up in America or severall poems, compiled with great variety of vvit and learning, full of delight. Wherein especially is contained a compleat discourse and description of the four elements, constitutions, ages of man, seasons of the year. Together with an exact epitomie of the four monarchies, viz. The Assyrian, Persian, Grecian, Roman. Also a dialogue between Old England and New, concerning the late troubles. With divers other pleasant and serious poems. By a gentlewoman in those parts.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p:
THE TENTH MUSE Lately Å¿prung up in AMERICA. OR Severall Poems, compiled with great variety of VVit and Learning, full of delight. Wherein eÅ¿pecially is contained a compleat diÅ¿courÅ¿e and deÅ¿cription of
The Four Elements,
The Four ConÅ¿titutions,
The Four Ages of Man,
The Four SeaÅ¿ons of the Year.

Together with an Exact Epitomie of the Four Monarchies, viz.
The AÅ¿Å¿yrian,
The PerÅ¿ian,
The Grecian,
The Roman.
AlÅ¿o a Dialogue between Old England and New, concerning the late troubles. With divers other pleaÅ¿ant and Å¿erious Poems.
By a Gentlewoman in thoÅ¿e parts.
Printed at London for Stephen Bowtell at the Å¿igne of the Bible in Popes Head-Alley. 1650.

HAd I opportunity but to borrow Å¿ome of the Authors wit, 'tis poÅ¿Å¿ible I might Å¿o trim this curious Work with Å¿uch quaint expreÅ¿sions, as that the Preface might beÅ¿peake thy further peruÅ¿all; but I feare 'twil be a Å¿hame for a man that can Å¿peak Å¿o little, to be Å¿eene in the title page of this Womans Book, leÅ¿t by comparing the one with the other, the Reader Å¿hould paÅ¿Å¿e his Å¿entence, that it is the gift of women, not only to Å¿peak moÅ¿t, but to Å¿peake beÅ¿t; I Å¿hall leave therefore to commend that, which with any ingenious Reader will too much commend the Author, unleÅ¿se men turne more peeviÅ¿h then women, to envie the excellency of the inÅ¿eriour Sex. I doubt not but the Reader will quickly finde more then I can Å¿ay, and the worÅ¿t effect of his reading will be unbeleif, which will make him queÅ¿tion whether it be a womans Work, and aske, Is it poÅ¿sible? If any doe, take this as an anÅ¿wer from him that dares avow it; It is the VVork of a VVoman, honoured, and eÅ¿teemed
where Å¿he lives, for her gracious demeanour, her eminent parts, her pious converÅ¿ation, her courteous diÅ¿poÅ¿ition, her exact diligence in her place, and diÅ¿creet mannaging of her family occaÅ¿ions; and more then Å¿o, theÅ¿e Poems are the fruit but of Å¿ome few houres, curtailed from her Å¿leep, and other refreÅ¿hments. I dare adde little, leÅ¿t I keepe thee too long, if thou wilt not beleeve the worth of theÅ¿e things (in their kind) when a man Å¿ayes it, yet beleeve it from a woman when thou Å¿eeÅ¿t it. This only I Å¿hall annex, I feare the diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ure of no perÅ¿on in the publiÅ¿hing of theÅ¿e Poems but the Authors, without whoÅ¿e knowledge, and contrary to her expectation, I have preÅ¿umed to bring to publick view what Å¿he reÅ¿olved Å¿hould never in Å¿uch a manner Å¿ee the Sun; but I found that divers had gotten Å¿ome Å¿cattered papers, affected them wel, were likely to have Å¿ent forth broken peices to the Authors prejudice, which I thought to prevent, as well as to pleaÅ¿ure thoÅ¿e that earneÅ¿tly deÅ¿ired the view of the whole.

lg.l: MErcury Å¿hew'd Apollo, Bartas Book,
Minerva this, and wiÅ¿ht him well to look,
And tell uprightly, which did which excell;
He view'd, and view'd, and vow'd he could not tell.
They bid him HemiÅ¿phear his mouldy noÅ¿e,
With's crackt leering-glaÅ¿Å¿es, for it would poÅ¿e
The beÅ¿t brains he had in's old pudding-pan,
Sex weigh'd, which beÅ¿t, the Woman, or the Man?
He peer'd, and por'd, and glar'd, and Å¿aid for wore,
I'me even as wiÅ¿e now, as I was before:
They both 'gan laugh, and Å¿aid, it was no mar'l
The Auth'reÅ¿Å¿e was a right Du Bartas Girle.
Good Å¿ooth quoth the old Don, tel, ye me Å¿o,
I muÅ¿e whither at length theÅ¿e Girls wil go;
It half revives my chil froÅ¿t-bitten blood,
To Å¿ee a woman once do, ought, that's good;
And chode buy Chaucers Boots, and Homers Furrs,
Ler men look to't, leaÅ¿t women weare the Spurs.

div.head: To my deare SiÅ¿ter, the Author of theÅ¿e Poems.

lg.l: THough moÅ¿t that know me, dare (I think) affirm
I ne're was borne to doe a Poet harm,
Yet when I read your pleaÅ¿ant witty Å¿trains,
It wrought Å¿o Å¿trongly on my addle brames;
That though my verÅ¿e be not Å¿o finely Å¿pun,
And Å¿o (like yours) cannot Å¿o neatly run,
Yet am I willing, with upright intent,
To Å¿hew my love without a complement.
There needs no painting to that comely face,
That in its native beauty hath Å¿uch grace;
What I (poore Å¿illy I) prefix therefore,
Can but doe this, make yours admir'd the more;
And if but only this, I doe attaine
Content, that my diÅ¿grace may be your gaine.
If women, I with women, may compare,
Your Works are Å¿olid, others weake as aire;
Some books of Women I have heard of late,
PeruÅ¿ed Å¿ome, Å¿o witleÅ¿Å¿e, intricate,
So void of Å¿ence, and truth, as if to erre
Were only wiÅ¿ht (acting above their Å¿phear)
And all to get, what (filly Å¿oules) they lack,
EÅ¿teeme to be the wiÅ¿eÅ¿t of the pack;
Though (for your Å¿ake) to Å¿ome this be permitted,
To print, yet wiÅ¿h I many better witted;
Their vanity make this to be inquired,
If women are with wit, and Å¿ence inÅ¿pired:
Yet when your Works Å¿hall come to publick view,
'Twill be affirm'd, 'twill be confirm'd by you:
And I, when Å¿eriouÅ¿ly I had revolved
What you had done, I preÅ¿ently reÅ¿olved,
Theirs was the PerÅ¿ons, not the Sexes failing,
And therefore did be-Å¿peak a modeÅ¿t vailing.
You have acutely in Eliza's ditty
Acquitted women, elÅ¿e I might with pitty,
Have wiÅ¿ht them all to womens Works to look,
And never more to meddle with their book.
What you have done, the Sun Å¿hall witneÅ¿Å¿e beare,
That for a womans Worke 'tis very rare;
And if the Nine vouchÅ¿afe the Tenth a place,
I think they rightly may yeeld you that grace.
But leaÅ¿t I Å¿hould exceed, and too much love,
Should too too much endear'd affection move,
To Å¿uper-adde in praiÅ¿es I Å¿hall ceaÅ¿e,
LeaÅ¿t while I pleaÅ¿e my Å¿elfe I Å¿hould diÅ¿pleaÅ¿e
The longing Reader, who may chance complaine,
And Å¿o requite my love with deep diÅ¿daine;
That I your Å¿illy Servant, Å¿tand i' th' porch,
Lighting your Sun-light with my blinking torch;
Hindring his minds content, his Å¿weet repoÅ¿e,
Which your delightfull Poems doe diÅ¿cloÅ¿e,
When once the Caskets op'ned; yet to you
Let this be added, then i'le bid adieu,
If you Å¿hall think, it will be to your Å¿hame
To be in print, then I muÅ¿t beare the blame:
I â¢ 't be a fault, 'tis mine, 'tis shame that might
Deny Å¿o faire an infant of its right,
To looke abroad; I know your modeÅ¿t minde,
How you will blush, complaine, 'tis too unkinde,
To force a womans birth, provoke her paine,
ExpoÅ¿e her Labours to the world's diÅ¿daine:
I know you'l Å¿ay, you doe defie that mint,
That Å¿tampt you thus, to be a foole in print,
'Tis true, it doth not now Å¿o neatly Å¿tand,
As ift 'twere polliÅ¿ht with your owne Å¿weet hand;
'Tis not Å¿o richly deckt, Å¿o trimly tir'd,
Yet it is Å¿uch as juÅ¿tly is admir'd.
If it be folly, 'tis of both, or neither,
Both you and I, we'l both be fools together;
And he that Å¿ayes, 'tis fooliÅ¿h (if my word
May Å¿way) by my conÅ¿ent Å¿hall make the third.
I dare out-face the worlds diÅ¿daine for both,
If you alone profeÅ¿Å¿e you are not wroth;
Yet if you are, a womans wrath is little,
When thouÅ¿ands elÅ¿e admire you in each tittle.

div.head: Upon the Author, by a knowne Friend.

l.hi: NOw I beleeve Tradition, which doth call
The MuÅ¿es, Vertues, Graces, Females all;
Only they are not nine, eleaven, nor three,
Our AuthreÅ¿Å¿e proves them but one unity.
Mankind take up Å¿ome bluÅ¿hes on the Å¿core,
Menopolize perfection no more:
In your owne Arts, confeÅ¿Å¿e your Å¿elves out-done,
The Moone hath totally ecclips'd the Sun,
Not with her Å¿able mantle mufling him,
But her bright Å¿ilver makes his gold looke dim:
JuÅ¿t as his beams force our pale Lamps to winke,
And earthly Fires within their aÅ¿hes Å¿hrinke.

lg.l: I cannot wonder at Apollo now,

l.hi: That he with Female Lawrell crown'd his brow,
That made him witty: had I leave to chuÅ¿e,
My VerÅ¿e Å¿hould be a Page unto your MuÅ¿e.

lg.l: ARme, arme, Soldado's arme, HorÅ¿e, HorÅ¿e, Å¿peed to your HorÅ¿es,
Gentle-women, make head, they vent their plots in VerÅ¿es;
They write of Monarchies, a moÅ¿t Å¿editious word,
It Å¿ignifies OppreÅ¿Å¿ion, Tyranny, and Sword:
March amain to London, they'l riÅ¿e, for there they flock,
But Å¿tay a while, they Å¿eldome riÅ¿e till ten a clock.

div.head: In praiÅ¿e of the Author, MiÅ¿tris Anne BradÅ¿treet, Vertue's true and lively Patterne, Wife of the WorÅ¿hipfull Simon BradÅ¿treet EÅ¿quire.
At preÅ¿ent reÅ¿iding in the Occidentall parts of the World, in America, alias NOV-ANGLIA.

l.hi: VVHat Golden Å¿plendent STAR is this, Å¿o bright,
One thouÅ¿and miles thrice told, both day and night,
(From th' Orient firÅ¿t Å¿prung) now from the WeÅ¿t

lg.l: That Å¿hines; Å¿wift-winged Phoebus, and the reÅ¿t,
Of all Joves fiery Å¿tames Å¿urmounting far,

l.hi: As doth each Planet, every falling Star;
By whoÅ¿e divine, and lucid light moÅ¿t cleare,
Natures darke Å¿ecret MyÅ¿teries appeare;
Heaven's, Earths admired wonders, noble acts
Of Kings, and Princes moÅ¿t heroick facts,
And what e're elÅ¿e in darknes Å¿eem'd to dye,
Revives all things Å¿o obvious now to th' eye;
That he who theÅ¿e, its glittering Rayes viewes o're,
Shall Å¿ee what's done in all the world before.

div.head: Upon the Author.

lg.l: TWere extreame folly Å¿hould I dare attempt,
To praiÅ¿e this Authors worth with complement;
None but her Å¿elf muÅ¿t dare commend her parts,
WhoÅ¿e Å¿ublime brain's the SynopÅ¿is of Arts:
Nature and Skil, here both in one agree,
To frame this MaÅ¿ter-peice of Poetry:
FalÅ¿e Fame, belye their Sex, no more, it can,
SurpaÅ¿Å¿e, or parallel, the beÅ¿t of man.

div.head: Another to Mris. Anne BradÅ¿treete, Author of this Poem.

lg.l: I'Ve read your Poem (Lady) and admire,
Your Sex, to Å¿uch a pitch Å¿hould e're aÅ¿pire;
Goe on to write, continue to relate,
New HiÅ¿tories, of Monarchy and State:
And what the Romans to their Poets gave,
Be Å¿ure Å¿uch honour, and eÅ¿teeme you'l have.
So Bartas like thy fine Å¿pun Poems been,
That Bartas name will prove an Epicene.

div.head: To her moÅ¿t Honoured Father Thomas Dudley EÅ¿q; theÅ¿e humbly preÅ¿ented.

lg.l: DEare Sir, of late delighted with the Å¿ight,
Of your T D. on the four parts of the world Å¿our Å¿iÅ¿ters, deckt in black & white
Of fairer Dames, the Å¿un near Å¿aw the face,
(though made a pedeÅ¿tall for Adams Race)
Their worth Å¿o Å¿hines, in thoÅ¿e rich lines you Å¿how.
Their paralells to find I Å¿carcely know,
To climbe their Climes, I have nor Å¿trength, nor skill,
To mount Å¿o high, requires an Eagles quill:
Yet view thereof, did cauÅ¿e my thoughts to Å¿oare,
My lowly pen, might wait upon thoÅ¿e four,
I bring my four; and four, now meanly clad,
To do their homage unto yours moÅ¿t glad,
Who for their age, their worth, and quality,
Might Å¿eem of yours to claime precedency;
But by my humble hand thus rudely pen'd
They are your bounden handmaids to attend.
TheÅ¿e Å¿ame are they, of whom we being have,
TheÅ¿e are of all, the life, the nurÅ¿e, the grave,
TheÅ¿e are, the hot, the cold, the moiÅ¿t, the dry,
That Å¿inke, that Å¿wim, that fill, that upwards flye,
Of theÅ¿e conÅ¿iÅ¿ts, our bodyes, cloathes, and food,
The world, the uÅ¿efull, hurtfull, and the good:
Sweet harmony they keep, yet jar oft times,
Their diÅ¿cord may appear, by theÅ¿e harÅ¿h rimes.
Yours did conteÅ¿t, for Wealth, for Arts, for Age,
My firÅ¿t do Å¿hew, their good, and then their rage,
My other four, do intermixed tell
Each others faults, and where themÅ¿elves excell:
How hot, and dry, contend with moiÅ¿t, and cold,
How Aire, and Earth, no correÅ¿pondence hold,
And yet in equall tempers, how they gree,
How divers natures, make one unity.
Some thing of all (though mean) I did intend,
But fear'd you'ld judge, one Bartas was my friend,
I honour him, but dare not wear his wealth,
My goods are true (though poor) I love no Å¿tealth,
But if I did, I durÅ¿t not Å¿end them you;
Who muÅ¿t reward a theife, but with his due.
I Å¿hall not need my innocence to clear,
TheÅ¿e ragged lines, will do't, when they appear.
On what they are, your mild aÅ¿pect I crave,
Accept my beÅ¿t, my worÅ¿t vouchÅ¿afe a grave.

div.l: From her, that to your Å¿elfe more duty owes,
Then waters, in the boundleÅ¿Å¿e Ocean flowes.

div.head: THE PROLOGUE.

lg.l: TO Å¿ing of Wars, of Captaines, and of Kings,
Of Cities founded, Common-wealths begun,
For my mean Pen, are too Å¿uperiour things,
And how they all, or each, their dates have run:
Let Poets, and HiÅ¿torians Å¿et theÅ¿e forth,
My obÅ¿cure VerÅ¿e, Å¿hal not Å¿o dim their worth.
But when my wondring eyes, and envious heart,
Great Bartas Å¿ugar'd lines doe but read o're;
Foole, I doe grudge, the MuÅ¿es did not part
'Twixt him and me, that over-fluent Å¿tore;
A Bartas can, doe what a Bartas wil,
But Å¿imple I, according to my skill.
From School-boyes tongue, no Rhethorick we expect,
Nor yet a Å¿weet ConÅ¿ort, from broken Å¿trings,
Nor perfect beauty, where's a maine defect,
My fooliÅ¿h, broken, blemiÅ¿h'd MuÅ¿e Å¿o Å¿ings;
And this to mend, alas, no Art is able,
'CauÅ¿e Nature made it Å¿o irreparable.
Nor can I, like that fluent Å¿weet tongu'd Greek
Who lisp'd at firÅ¿t, Å¿peake afterwards more plaine
By Art, he gladly found what he did Å¿eeke,
A full requitall of his Å¿triving paine:
Art can doe much, but this maxime's moÅ¿t Å¿ure,
A weake or wounded braine admits no cure.
Iam obnoxious to each carping tongue,
Who Å¿ayes, my hand a needle better fits,
A Poets Pen, all Å¿corne, I Å¿hould thus wrong;
For Å¿uch deÅ¿pight they caÅ¿t on female wits:
If what I doe prove well, it wo'nt advance,
They'l Å¿ay its Å¿tolne, or elÅ¿e, it was by chance.
But Å¿ure the antick Greeks were far more milde,
ElÅ¿e of our Sex, why feigned they thoÅ¿e nine,
And poeÅ¿y made, Calliope's owne childe,
So 'mongÅ¿t the reÅ¿t, they plac'd the Arts divine:
But this weake knot they will full Å¿oone untye,
The Greeks did nought, but play the foole and lye.
Let Greeks be Greeks, and Women what they are,
Men have precedency, and Å¿till excell,
It is but vaine, unjuÅ¿tly to wage war,
Men can doe beÅ¿t, and Women know it well;
Preheminence in each, and all is yours,
Yet grant Å¿ome Å¿mall acknowledgement of ours.
And oh, ye high flown quils, that Å¿oare the skies,
And ever with your prey, Å¿till catch your praiÅ¿e,
If e're you daigne theÅ¿e lowly lines, your eyes
Give wholÅ¿ome ParÅ¿ley wreath, I aske no Bayes:
This meane and unrefined Å¿tuffe of mine,
Will make your gliÅ¿tering gold but more to Å¿hine.

div.head: The Foure Elements.

lg.l: FIre, Aire, Earth, and Water, did all conteÅ¿t
which was the Å¿trongeÅ¿t, nobleÅ¿t, & the beÅ¿t,
Who the moÅ¿t good could Å¿hew, & who moÅ¿t rage
For to declare, themÅ¿elves they all ingage;
And in due order each her turne Å¿hould Å¿peake,
But enmity, this amity did breake:
All would be cheife, and all Å¿corn'd to be under,
Whence iÅ¿Å¿u'd raines, and winds, lightning and thunder;
The quaking Earth did groan, the skie look't black,
The Fire, the forced Aire, in Å¿under crack;
The Å¿ea did threat the heavens, the heavens the earth,
All looked like a Chaos, or new birth;
Fire broyled Earth, and Å¿corched Earth it choaked,
Both by their darings; Water Å¿o provoked,
That roaring in it came, and with its Å¿ource
Soone made the combatants abate their force;
The rumbling, hiÅ¿Å¿ing, puffing was Å¿o great,
The worlds confuÅ¿ion it did Å¿eeme to threat;
But Aire at length, contention Å¿o abated,
That betwixt hot and cold, Å¿he arbitrated
The others enmity: being leÅ¿Å¿e, did ceaÅ¿e
All Å¿tormes now laid, and they in perfect peace,
That Fire Å¿hould firÅ¿t begin, the reÅ¿t conÅ¿ent,
Being the moÅ¿t impatient Element.

lg.head: Fire.
lg.l: WHat is my worth (both ye) and all things know,
Where little is, I can but little Å¿how,
But what I am, let learned Grecians Å¿ay;
What I can doe, well skill'd Mechanicks may,
The benefit all Beings, by me finde;
Come firÅ¿t ye ArtiÅ¿ts, and declare your minde.
What toole was ever fram'd, but by my might;
O MartialiÅ¿t! what weapon for your fight?
To try your valour by, but it muÅ¿t feele
My force? your Å¿word, your Pike, your flint and Å¿teele,
Your Cannon's bootleÅ¿Å¿e, and your powder too
Without mine ayd, alas, what can they doe?
The adverÅ¿e wall's not Å¿hak'd, the Mine's not blowne,
And in deÅ¿pight the City keeps her owne,
But I with one Granado, or Petard,
Set ope thoÅ¿e gates, that 'fore Å¿o Å¿trong was barr'd,
Ye Husband-men, your coulter's made by me,
Your Å¿hares, your mattocks, and what e're you Å¿ee,
Subdue the earth, and fit it for your graine,
That Å¿o in time it might requite your paine;
Though Å¿trong limb'd Vulcan forg'd it by his skill,
I m â¢â¢ e it flexible unto his will.
Ye Cooks, your kitchin implements I fram'd,
Your Å¿pits, pots, jacks, what elÅ¿e I need not name,
Your dainty food, I wholÅ¿ome make, I warme
Your Å¿hrinking limbs, which winters cold doth harme;
Ye ParacelÅ¿ians too, in vaine's your skil
In chymeÅ¿try, unleÅ¿Å¿e I help you Stil,
And you PhiloÅ¿ophers, if ere you made
A tranÅ¿mutation, it was through mine aide.
Ye Silver-Å¿miths, your ure I do refine,
What mingled lay with earth, I cauÅ¿e to Å¿hine.
But let me leave theÅ¿e things, my flame aÅ¿pires
To match on high with the CeleÅ¿tiall fires.
The Sun, an Orbe of Fire was held of old,
Our Sages new, another tale have told:
But be he what they liÅ¿t, yet his aÅ¿pect,
A burning fiery heat we find reflect;
And of the Å¿elfe Å¿ame nature is with mine,
Good Å¿iÅ¿ter Earth, no witneÅ¿Å¿e needs but thine;
How doth his warmth refreÅ¿h thy frozen backs,
And trim thee gay, in green, after thy blacks?
Both man and beaÅ¿t, rejoyce at his approach,
And birds do Å¿ing, to Å¿ee his glittering Coach.
And though nought but Sal'manders live in fire;
The Flye PyrauÅ¿ta cal'd, all â¢ elÅ¿e expire.
Yet men and beaÅ¿ts, AÅ¿tronomers can tell,
Fixed in heavenly conÅ¿tellations dwell,
My Planets, of both Sexes, whoÅ¿e degree,
Poor Heathen judg'd worthy a Diety:
With Orion arm'd, attended by his dog,
The Theban Å¿tout Alcides, with his club:
The Valiant PerÅ¿eus who MeduÅ¿a Å¿lew,
The HorÅ¿e that kill'd Bellerophon, then flew.
My Crabbe, my Scorpion, fiÅ¿hes, you may Å¿ee,
The maid with ballance, wayn with horÅ¿es three;
The Ram, the Bull, the Lyon, and the Beagle;
The Bear, the Goate, the Raven, and the Eagle,
The Crown, the Whale, the Archer, Bernice Hare,
The Hidra, Dolphin, Boys, that waters bear.
Nay more then theÅ¿e, Rivers 'mongÅ¿t Å¿tars are found,
Eridanus, where Phaeton was drown'd,
Their magnitude and height Å¿hould I recount,
My Å¿tory to a Volume would amount:
Out of a multitude, theÅ¿e few I touch,
Your wiÅ¿dom out of little gathers much,
Ile here let paÅ¿Å¿e, my Choler cauÅ¿e of warres,
And influence of divers of thoÅ¿e Å¿tarres,
When in conjunction with the Å¿un, yet more,
Augment his heat, which was too hot before:
The Summer ripening Å¿eaÅ¿on I do claime;
And man from thirty unto fifty frame.
Of old, when Sacrifices were divine,
I of acceptance was the holy Å¿igne.
'Mong all my wonders which I might recount;
There's none more Å¿trange then Aetna's Å¿ulphery mount
The choaking flames, that from VeÅ¿uvius flew
The over-curious Å¿econd Pliny Å¿lew:
And with the aÅ¿hes, that it Å¿ometimes Å¿hed
Apulia's jacent parts were covered;
And though I be a Å¿ervant to each man;
Yet by my force, maÅ¿ter my maÅ¿ter can.
What famous Townes to cinders have I turn'd?
What laÅ¿ting Forts my kindleed wrath hath burn'd?
The Å¿tately Å¿eats of mighty Kings by me:
In confus'd heaps of aÅ¿hes may ye Å¿ee.
Where's Ninus great wal'd Town, and Troy of old?
Carthage, and hundred moe â¢ in Å¿tories told,
Which when they could not be o're come by foes
The Army through my helpe victorious roÅ¿e;
Old Å¿acred Zion, I demoliÅ¿h'd thee;
So great Diana's Temple was by me.
And more then bruitiÅ¿h Sodome for her luÅ¿t,
With neighbouring Townes I did conÅ¿ume to duÅ¿t,
What Å¿hal I Å¿ay of Lightning, and of Thunder,
Which Kings, and mighty ones; amaz'd with wonder,
Which made a CaeÅ¿ar, (Romes) the worlds proud head,
FooliÅ¿h Caligula, creep under's bed
Of Metors, Ignis Fatuus, and the reÅ¿t,
But to leave thoÅ¿e to'th' wiÅ¿e, I judge is beÅ¿t,
The rich I oft make poore, the Å¿trong I maime,
Not Å¿paring life when I can take the Å¿ame;
And in a word, the World I Å¿hal conÅ¿ume,
And all therein at that great day of doome;
Not before then, Å¿hal ceaÅ¿e my raging ire,
And then, becauÅ¿e no matter more for fire:
Now SiÅ¿ters, pray proceed, each in her courÅ¿e,
As I: impart your uÅ¿efulneÅ¿Å¿e, and force.

lg.head: Earth.
lg.l: THe next in place, Earth judg'd to be her due,
SiÅ¿ter, in worth I come not Å¿hort of you;
In wealth and uÅ¿e I doe Å¿urpaÅ¿Å¿e you all,
And Mother Earth, of old, men did me call,
Such was my fruitfulneÅ¿Å¿e; an Epithite
Which none ere gave, nor you could claime of right,
Among my praiÅ¿es this I count not leaÅ¿t,
I am th' originall of man and beaÅ¿t,
To tell what Å¿undry fruits my fat Å¿oyle yeelds,
In vine-yards, orchards, gardens, and corne fields,
Their kinds, their taÅ¿ts, their colours, and their Å¿mels,
Would Å¿o paÅ¿Å¿e time, I could Å¿ay nothing elÅ¿e;
The rich and poore, wiÅ¿e, foole, and every Å¿ort,
Of theÅ¿e Å¿o common things, can make report:
To tell you of my Countries, and my regions
Soone would they paÅ¿Å¿e, not hundreds, but legions,
My cities famous, rich, and populous,
WhoÅ¿e numbers now are growne innumerous;
I have not time to thinke of every part,
Yet let me name my Grecia, 'tis my heart
For Learning, Armes, and Arts, I love it well:
But chiefly, 'cauÅ¿e the MuÅ¿es there did dwell;
I'le here skip o're my mountaines, reaching skies,
Whether Pyrenian, or the Alpes; both lyes
On either Å¿ide the country of the Gaules,
Strong forts from SpaniÅ¿h and Italian braules,
And huge great Taurus, longer then the reÅ¿t,
Dividing great Armenia from the leaÅ¿t,
And Hemus, whoÅ¿e Å¿teep Å¿ides, none foote upon,
But farewell all, for deare mount Helicon,
And wonderous high Olimpus, of Å¿uch fame,
That heaven it Å¿elfe was oft call'd by that name;
Sweet ParnaÅ¿Å¿us, I dote too much on thee,
UnleÅ¿Å¿e thou prove a better friend to me;
But ile skip o're theÅ¿e Hills, not touch a Dale,
Nor yet expatiate, in Temple vale;
Ile here let goe, my Lions of Numedia,
My Panthers, and my Leopards of Libia,
The Behemoth, and rare found Unicorne,
PoyÅ¿ons Å¿ure antidote lyes in his horne.
And my Hyaena (imitates mans voyce)
Out of huge numbers, I might pick my choyce,
ThouÅ¿ands in woods, and planes, both wild, and tame,
But here, or there, I liÅ¿t now none to name;
No, though the fawning dog did urge me Å¿ore
In his behalfe to Å¿peak a word the more;
WhoÅ¿e truÅ¿t, and valour I might here commend:
But time's too Å¿hort, and precious Å¿o to Å¿pend.
But hark, ye worthy Merchants who for prize
Send forth your well man'd Å¿hips, where Å¿un doth riÅ¿e.
After three years, when men and meat is Å¿pent,
My rich commodities payes double rent.
Ye GaleniÅ¿ts, my Drugs that come from thence
Doe cure your patients, fill your purÅ¿e with pence;
BeÅ¿ides the uÅ¿e you have, of Hearbs and Plants,
That with leÅ¿Å¿e coÅ¿t, neare home, Å¿upplyes your wants.
But Marriners, where got you Å¿hips and Å¿ailes?
And Oares to row, when both my Å¿iÅ¿ters failes?
Your Tackling, Anchor, CompaÅ¿Å¿e too, is mine;
Which guides, when Sun, nor Moon, nor Stars do Å¿hine.
Ye mighty Kings, who for your laÅ¿ting fames
Built Cities, Monuments call'd by your names;
Was thoÅ¿e compiled heapes of maÅ¿Å¿y Å¿tones?
That your ambition laid, ought but my bones?
Ye greedy miÅ¿ers who do dig for gold;
For gemmes, for Å¿ilver, treaÅ¿ures which I hold:
Will not my goodly face, your rage Å¿uffice?
But you will Å¿ee what in my bowels lyes?
And ye Artificers, all trades and Å¿orts;
My bounty calls you forth to make reports,
If ought you have to uÅ¿e, to wear, to eate?
But what I freely yeeld upon your Å¿weat?
And cholerick Å¿iÅ¿ter, thou (for all thine ire)
Well knoweÅ¿t, my fuell muÅ¿t maintain thy fire.
As I ingenuouÅ¿ly (with thanks) confeÅ¿Å¿e
My cold, thy (fruitfull) heat, doth crave no leÅ¿Å¿e:
But how my cold, dry temper, works upon
The melancholy conÅ¿titution.
How the Autumnal Å¿eaÅ¿on I do Å¿way;
And how I force the grey head to obey.
I Å¿hould here make a Å¿hort, yet true narration,
But that thy method is my imitation.
Now might I Å¿hew my adverÅ¿e quality,
And how I oft work mans mortality.
He Å¿ometimes findes, maugre his toyling paine,
ThiÅ¿tles and thornes, where he expected graine;
My Å¿ap, to plants and trees, I muÅ¿t not grant,
The Vine, the Olive, and the Figtree want:
The Corne, and Hay, both fall before they'r mowne;
And buds from fruitfull trees, before they'r blowne.
Then dearth prevailes, that Nature to Å¿uffice,
The tender mother on her Infant flyes:
The Husband knowes no Wife, nor father Å¿ons;
But to all outrages their hunger runnes.
Dreadfull examples, Å¿oon I might produce,
But to Å¿uch auditours 'twere of no uÅ¿e.
Again, when Delvers dare in hope of gold,
To ope thoÅ¿e veines of Mine, audacious bold:
While they thus in my intralls Å¿eem to dive;
Before they know, they are inter'd alive.
Ye affrighted wights, appall'd how do you Å¿hake
If once you feele me, your foundation, quake,
BecauÅ¿e in the abyÅ¿Å¿e of my darke wombe:
Your Cities and your Å¿elves I oft intombe.
O dreadfull Sepulcher! that this is true,
Korah and all his Company well knew.
And Å¿ince, faire Italy full Å¿adly knowes
What Å¿he hath loÅ¿t by theÅ¿e my dreadfull woes.
And Rome, her Curtius, can't forget I think;
Who bravely rode into my yawning chinke.
Again, what veines of poyÅ¿on in me lye;
As Stibium and unfixt Mercury:
With divers moe, nay, into plants it creeps;
In hot, and cold, and Å¿ome benums with Å¿leeps,
Thus I occaÅ¿ion death to man and beaÅ¿t,
When they Å¿eek food, and harme miÅ¿truÅ¿t the leaÅ¿t.
Much might I Å¿ay, of the Arabian Å¿ands;
Which riÅ¿e like mighty billowes on the lands:
Wherein whole Armies I have overthrown;
But windy Å¿iÅ¿ter, 'twas when you have blown.
Ile Å¿ay no more, yet this thing adde I muÅ¿t,
Remember Å¿onnes, your mould is of my duÅ¿t,
And after death, whether inter'd, or burn'd;
As earth at firÅ¿t, Å¿o into earth return'd.

lg.head: Water.
lg.l: SCarce Earth had done, but th' angry waters mov'd;
SiÅ¿ter (quoth Å¿he) it had full well behov'd
Among your boaÅ¿tings to have praiÅ¿ed me;
CauÅ¿e of your fruitfulneÅ¿Å¿e, as you Å¿hall Å¿ee:
This your neglect, Å¿hewes your ingratitude;
And how your Å¿ubtilty would men delude.
Not one of us, all knowes, that's like to thee,
Ever in craving, from the other three:
But thou art bound to me, above the reÅ¿t;
Which am thy drink, thy blood, thy Å¿ap, and beÅ¿t.
If I withhold, what art thou, dead, dry lump
Thou bear'Å¿t no graÅ¿Å¿e, nor plant, nor tree, nor Å¿tump.
Thy extream thirÅ¿t is moiÅ¿tened by my love,
With Å¿prings below, and Å¿howers from above;
Or elÅ¿e thy Å¿un-burnt face, and gaping chapps;
Complaines to th'heaven, when I withhold my drops:
Thy Bear, thy Tyger, and thy Lyon Å¿tout,
When I am gone, their fierceneÅ¿Å¿e none need doubt;
The Camell hath no Å¿trength, thy Bull no force;
Nor mettl's found in the couragious HorÅ¿e:
Hindes leave their Calves, the Elephant the Fens;
The Woolves and Å¿avage BeaÅ¿ts, forÅ¿ake their Dens.
The lofty Eagle and the Storke flye low,
The Peacock, and the OÅ¿trich, Å¿hare in woe:
The Pine, the Cedars, yea and Daph'nes tree;
Do ceaÅ¿e to flouriÅ¿h in this miÅ¿ery.
Man wants his bread, and wine, and pleaÅ¿ant fruits;
He knowes Å¿uch Å¿weets, lyes not in earths dry roots,
Then Å¿eeks me out, in River and in Well;
His deadly mallady, I might expell.
If I Å¿upply, his heart and veines rejoyce;
If nor, Å¿oon ends his life, as did his voyce.
That this is true, earth thou canÅ¿t not deny;
I call thine Egypt, this to verifie;
Which by my fatting Nile, doth yeeld Å¿uch Å¿tore;
That Å¿he can Å¿pare, when Nations round are poore.
When I run low, and not o're flow her brinks;
To meet with want, each woefull man bethinks.
But Å¿uch I am, in Rivers, Å¿howers and Å¿prings;
But what's the wealth that my rich Ocean brings?
FiÅ¿hes Å¿o numberleÅ¿Å¿e I there do hold;
ShouldÅ¿t thou but buy, it would exhauÅ¿t thy gold.
There lives the oyly Whale, whom all men know,
Such wealth, but not Å¿uch like, Earth thou mayÅ¿t Å¿how.
The Dolphin (loving muÅ¿ique) Arions friend.
The crafty Barbell, whoÅ¿e wit doth her commend;
With thouÅ¿ands moe, which now I liÅ¿t not name,
Thy Å¿ilence of thy beaÅ¿ts, doth cauÅ¿e the Å¿ame.
My pearles that dangle at thy darlings ears;
Not thou, but Å¿hell-fiÅ¿h yeelds, as Pliny clears.
Was ever gem Å¿o rich found in thy trunke?
As Aegypts wanton Cleopatra drunke.
Or haÅ¿t thou any colour can come nigh;
The Roman Purple, double Tirian dye.
Which CaeÅ¿ars, ConÅ¿uls, Tribunes all adorne;
For it, to Å¿earch my waves, they thought no Å¿corne.
Thy gallant rich perfuming Amber-greece:
I lightly caÅ¿t a Å¿hoare as frothy fleece.
With rowling graines of pureÅ¿t maÅ¿Å¿y gold:
Which Spaines Americans, do gladly hold.
Earth, thou haÅ¿t not more Countrys, Vales and Mound â¢ ,
Then I have Fountaines, Rivers, Lakes and Ponds:
My Å¿undry Seas, Black, VVhite, and Adriatique
Ionian, Balticke, and the vaÅ¿t Atlantique;
The Ponticke, CaÅ¿pian, Golden Rivers fine.
AÅ¿phaltis Lake, where nought remains alive.
But I Å¿hould go beyond thee in thy boaÅ¿ts,
If I Å¿hould Å¿hew, more Seas, then thou haÅ¿t CoaÅ¿ts.
But note this maxime in PhiloÅ¿ophy:
Then Seas are deep, Mountains are never high.
To Å¿peake of kinds of VVaters I'le neglect,
My divers Fountaines and their Å¿trange effect;
My wholeÅ¿ome Bathes, together with their cures.
My water Syrens, with their guilefull lures:
Th' uncertain cauÅ¿e, of certain ebbs and flowes;
VVhich wondring AriÅ¿ â¢ o â¢ les wit, ne'r knowes.
Nor will I Å¿peake of waters made by Art,
Which can to life, reÅ¿tore a fainting heart:
Nor fruitfull dewes, nor drops from weeping eyes;
VVhich pitty moves, and oft deceives the wiÅ¿e.
Nor yet of Salt, and Sugar, Å¿weet and Å¿mart,
Both when we liÅ¿t, to water we convert.
Alas; thy Å¿hips and oares could do no good
Did they but want my Ocean, and my Flood.
The wary Merchant, on his weary beaÅ¿t
Transfers his goods, from North and South and EaÅ¿t;
UnleÅ¿Å¿e I eaÅ¿e his toyle, and doe tranÅ¿port,
The wealthy fraught, unto his wiÅ¿hed Port.
TheÅ¿e be my benefits which may Å¿uffice:
I now muÅ¿t Å¿hew what force there in me lyes.
The flegmy conÅ¿titution I uphold;
All humours, Tumours, that are bred of cold.
O're childehood, and Winter, I bear the Å¿way;
Yet Luna for my Regent I obey.
As I with Å¿howers oft time refreÅ¿h the earth;
So oft in my exceÅ¿Å¿e, I cauÅ¿e a dearth:
And with aboundant wet, Å¿o coole the ground,
By adding cold to cold, no fruit proves Å¿ound;
The Farmer, and the Plowman both complain
Of rotten Å¿heep, lean kine, and mildew'd grain.
And with my waÅ¿ting floods, and roaring torrent;
Their Cattle, Hay, and Corne, I Å¿weep down current,
Nay many times, my Ocean breaks his bounds:
And with aÅ¿toniÅ¿hment, the world confounds.
And Å¿wallowes Countryes up, ne're Å¿een againe:
And that an IÅ¿land makes, which once was maine.
Thus Albion (tis thought) was cut from France,
Cicily from Italy, by th'like chance.
And but one land was Affriea and Spayne,
Untill Å¿traight Gibralter, did make them twaine.
Some Å¿ay I Å¿wallowed up (Å¿ure 'tis a notion)
A mighty Country ith' Atlanticke Ocean.
I need not Å¿ay much of my Haile and Snow,
My Ice and extream cold, which all men know.
VVhereof the firÅ¿t, Å¿o ominous I rain'd,
That IÅ¿raels enemies, therewith was brain'd.
And of my chilling colds, Å¿uch plenty be;
That CaucaÅ¿us high mounts, are Å¿eldom free.
Mine Ice doth glaze Europs big'Å¿t Rivers o're,
Till Sun releaÅ¿e, their Å¿hips can Å¿aile no more.
All know, what innundations I have made;
VVherein not men, but mountaines Å¿eem'd to wade
As when Achaia, all under water Å¿tood,
That in two hundred year, it ne'r prov'd good.
Ducalions great deluge, with many moe;
But theÅ¿e are trifles to the Flood of Noe.
Then wholly periÅ¿h'd, earths ignoble race;
And to this day, impaires her beautious face.
That after times, Å¿hall never feel like woe:
Her confirm'd Å¿onnes, behold my colour'd bow.
Much might I Å¿ay of wracks, but that Ile Å¿pare,
And now give place unto our Å¿iÅ¿ter Aire.

lg.head: Aire.
lg.l: COntent (quoth Aire) to Å¿peake the laÅ¿t of you,
Though not through ignorance, firÅ¿t was my due,
I doe Å¿uppoÅ¿e, you'l yeeld without controle;
I am the breath of every living Å¿oul.
Mortalls, what one of you, that loves not me,
Aboundantly more then my Å¿iÅ¿ters three?
And though you love Fire, Earth, and VVater wel;
Yet Aire, beyond all theÅ¿e ye know t'excell.
I aske the man condemn'd, that's near his death:
How gladly Å¿hould his gold purchaÅ¿e his breath,
And all the wealth, that ever earth did give,
How freely Å¿hould it go, Å¿o he might live.
No world, thy witching traÅ¿h, were all but vain.
If my pure Aire, thy Å¿onnes did not Å¿uÅ¿tain.
The famiÅ¿ht, thirÅ¿ty man, that craves Å¿upply:
His moveing reaÅ¿on is, give leaÅ¿t I dye.
So loath he is to go, though nature's Å¿pent,
To bid a due, to his dear Element.
Nay, what are words, which doe reveale the mind?
Speak, who, or what they will, they are but wind.
Your Drums, your Trumpets, and your Organs Å¿ound,
VVhat is't? but forced Aire which muÅ¿t rebound,
And Å¿uch are Ecchoes, and report o'th gun
VVhich tells afar, th' exployt which he hath done.
Your Å¿ongs and pleaÅ¿ant tunes, they are the Å¿ame,
And Å¿o's the notes which Nightingales do frame.
Ye forging Smiths, if Bellowes once were gone;
Your red hot work, more coldly would go on.
Ye Mariners, tis I that fill your Sailes,
And Å¿peed you to your Port, with wiÅ¿hed gales.
VVhen burning heat, doth cauÅ¿e you faint, I coole,
And when I Å¿mile, your Ocean's like a Poole.
I ripe the corne, I turne the grinding mill;
And with my Å¿elfe, I every vacuum fill.
The ruddy Å¿weet Å¿anguine, is like to Aire,
And youth, and Å¿pring, Å¿ages to me compare.
My moiÅ¿t hot nature, is Å¿o purely thinne,
No place Å¿o Å¿ubtilly made, but I get in.
I grow more pure and pure, as I mount higher,
And when I'm throughly rarifi'd, turn fire.
So when I am condens'd, I turne to water;
VVhich may be done, by holding down my vapour.
Thus I another body can aÅ¿Å¿ume,
And in a trice, my own nature reÅ¿ume.
Some for this cauÅ¿e (of late) have been Å¿o bold,
Me for no Element, longer to hold.
Let Å¿uch Å¿uÅ¿pend their thoughts, and Å¿ilent be;
For all PhiloÅ¿ophers make one of me.
And what thoÅ¿e Sages, did, or Å¿pake, or writ,
Is more authentick then their moderne wit.
Next, of my Fowles Å¿uch multitudes there are;
Earths BeaÅ¿ts, and VVaters FiÅ¿h, Å¿carce can compare.
The OÅ¿trich with her plumes, th'Eagle with her eyne;
The Phoenix too (if any be) are mine;
The Stork, the Crane, the Partrich, and the PheÅ¿ant;
The Pye, the Jay, the Larke, a prey to th' PeaÅ¿ant.
VVith thouÅ¿ands moe, which now I may omit;
VVithout impeachment, to my tale or wit.
As my freÅ¿h Aire preÅ¿erves, all things in life;
So when 'ts corrupt, mortality is rife.
Then Feavours, Purples, Pox, and PeÅ¿tilence;
VVith divers more, worke deadly conÅ¿equence.
VVhereof Å¿uch multitudes have dy'd and fled,
The living, Å¿carce had power, to bury dead.
Yea Å¿o contagious, Countries have me known;
That birds have not Å¿cap'd death, as they have flown,
Of murrain, Cattle numberleÅ¿Å¿e did fall.
Men fear'd deÅ¿truction epidemicall.
Then of my tempeÅ¿ts, felt at Sea and Land,
Which neither Å¿hips nor houÅ¿es could withÅ¿tand.
What woeful wracks I've made, may wel appear,
If nought was known, but that before Algire.
Where famous Charles the fift, more loÅ¿Å¿e Å¿uÅ¿tain'd,
Then in his long hot wars, which Millain gain'd.
How many rich fraught veÅ¿Å¿ells, have I Å¿plit?
Some upon Å¿ands, Å¿ome upon rocks have hit.
Some have I forc'd, to gaine an unknown Å¿hoare;
Some overwelm'd with waves, and Å¿een no more.
Again, what tempeÅ¿ts, and what hericanoes
Knowes VVeÅ¿tern IÅ¿les, ChriÅ¿tophers, Barbadoes;
VVhere neither houÅ¿es, trees, nor plants, I Å¿pare;
But Å¿ome fall down, and Å¿ome flye up with aire.
Earth-quaks Å¿o hurtful and Å¿o fear'd of all,
ImpriÅ¿oned I, am the original.
Then what prodigious Å¿ights, Å¿ometimes I Å¿how:
As battells pitcht ith' Aire (as Countries know;)
Their joyning, fighting, forcing, and retreat;
That earth appeares in heaven, oh wonder great!
Sometimes Å¿trange flaming Å¿words, and blazing Å¿tars,
Portentious Å¿ignes, of Famines, Plagues and VVars.
VVhich makes the mighty Monarchs fear their Fates,
By death, or great mutations of their States.
I have Å¿aid leÅ¿Å¿e, then did my Å¿iÅ¿ters three;
But what's their worth, or force, but more's in me.
To adde to all I've Å¿aid, was my intent,
But dare not go, beyond my Element.

div.head: Of the foure Humours in Mans conÅ¿titution.

lg.l: THe former foure, now ending their DiÅ¿courÅ¿e,
CeaÅ¿ing to vaunt, their good, or threat their force.
Loe! other foure Å¿tep up, crave leave to Å¿hew
The native qualities, that from each flow,
But firÅ¿t they wiÅ¿ely Å¿hew'd their high deÅ¿cent,
Each eldeÅ¿t Daughter to each Element;
Choler was own'd by Fire, and Blood by Aire,
Earth knew her black Å¿warth childe, Water her faire;
All having made obeyÅ¿ance to each Mother,
Had leave to Å¿peake, Å¿ucceeding one the other;
But 'mongÅ¿t themÅ¿elves they were at variance,
Which of the foure Å¿hould have predominance;
Choler hotly claim'd, right by her mother,
Who had precedency of all the other.
But Sanguine did diÅ¿daine, what Å¿he requir'd,
Pleading her Å¿elfe, was moÅ¿t of all deÅ¿ir'd;
Proud Melancholy, more envious then the reÅ¿t,
The Å¿econd, third, or laÅ¿t could not digeÅ¿t;
She was the Å¿ilenceÅ¿t of all the foure,
Her wiÅ¿edome Å¿pake not much, but thought the more.
Cold flegme, did not conteÅ¿t for higheÅ¿t place,
Only Å¿he crav'd, to have a vacant Å¿pace.
Wel, thus they parle, and chide, but to be briefe,
Or wil they nil they, Choler wil be cheife;
They Å¿eeing her imperioÅ¿ity,
At preÅ¿ent yeelded, to neceÅ¿Å¿ity.

lg.head: Choler.
lg.l: TO Å¿hew my great deÅ¿cent, and pedigree,
Your Å¿elves would judge, but vain prolixity.
It is acknowledged, from whence I came,
It Å¿hal Å¿uffice, to tel you what I am:
My Å¿elf, and Mother, one as you Å¿hal Å¿ee,
But Å¿he in greater, I in leÅ¿Å¿e degree;
We both once MaÅ¿culines, the world doth know,
Now Feminines (a while) for love we owe
Unto your SiÅ¿ter-hood, which makes us tender
Our noble Å¿elves, in a leÅ¿Å¿e noble Gender.
Though under fire, we comprehend all heat,
Yet man for Choler, is the proper Å¿eat.
I in his heart erect my regal throne,
Where Monarch-like I play, and Å¿way alone,
Yet many times, unto my great diÅ¿grace,
One of your Å¿elves are my compeers, in place:
Where if your rule once grow predominant,
The man proves boyiÅ¿h, Å¿ottiÅ¿h, ignorant,
But if ye yeeld Å¿ub-Å¿ervient unto me,
I make a man, a man i'th higheÅ¿t degree,
Be he a Souldier, I more fence his heart
Then Iron CorÅ¿let, 'gainÅ¿t a Å¿word or dart;
What makes him face his foe, without appal?
To Å¿torme a Breach, or Å¿cale a City wal?
In dangers to account himÅ¿elf more Å¿ure,
Then timerous Hares, whom CaÅ¿tles doe immure?
Have ye not heard of Worthies, Demi-gods?
'Twixt them and others, what iÅ¿t makes the odds
But valour, whence comes that? from none of you;
Nay milk-Å¿ops, at Å¿uch brunts you look but blew,
Here's SiÅ¿ter Ruddy, worth the other two,
That much wil talk, but little dares Å¿he do,
UnleÅ¿Å¿e to court, and claw, and dice, and drink,
And there Å¿he wil out-bid us all, I think;
She loves a Fiddle, better then a Drum,
A Chamber wel, in field Å¿he dares not come;
She'l ride a HorÅ¿e as bravely, as the beÅ¿t,
And break a Å¿taffe, provided't be in jeÅ¿t,

So loving unto all, Å¿he Å¿cornes to fight.

Here's three of you, all Å¿ees now what you are,

Again, who fits, for learning, Å¿cience, Arts?
Who rarifies the intellectuall parts?
Whence flow fine Å¿pirits, and witty notions?
Not from our dul Å¿low SiÅ¿ters motions:
Nor Å¿iÅ¿ter Sanguine, from thy moderate heat,
Poor Å¿pirits the Liver breeds, which is thy Å¿eat,
What comes from thence, my heat refines the Å¿ame,

The vitall Å¿pirits they're call'd, and wel they may,

The Animal I claime, as wel as theÅ¿e,
The nerves Å¿hould I not warm, Å¿oon would they freeze.
But Flegme her Å¿elf, is now provok'd at this,
She thinks I never Å¿hot Å¿o farre amiÅ¿Å¿e;
The Brain Å¿he challenges, the Head's her Å¿eat,
But know'ts a fooliÅ¿h brain, that wanteth heat;

Oh, who would miÅ¿Å¿e this influence of thine,

No, no, thou haÅ¿t no Å¿pirits, thy company

The PalÅ¿ie, Gout, or Cramp, or Å¿ome Å¿uch dolor,

Thou Å¿ayÅ¿t, thy wits are Å¿tai'd, Å¿ubtle and fine:

Thou canÅ¿t not claime, the Liver, Head nor Heart;

If once thou'rt great, what followes thereupon?
But bodies waÅ¿ting, and deÅ¿truction.
So baÅ¿e thou art, that baÅ¿er cannot be;
The excrement, aduÅ¿tion of me.
But I am weary to dilate thy Å¿hame;
Nor is't my pleaÅ¿ure, thus to blur thy name:
Onely to raiÅ¿e my honours to the Skyes,

Thus arms, and arts I claim, and higher things;
The Princely quality, befitting Kings.
WhoÅ¿e Serene heads, I line with policies,

Like our fixt Henry, that Å¿ame worthy thing.
That when a Varlet, Å¿truck him o're the Å¿ide,
ForÅ¿ooth you are to blame, he grave reply'd.
Take choler from a Prince, what is he more,

Again, ye know, how I act every part:
By th' influence I Å¿end Å¿till from the heart.
Its not your muÅ¿cles, nerves, nor this nor that:

The Å¿pongy Lungs, I feed with frothy blood.

I have been Å¿paring, what I might have Å¿aid,

To what you now Å¿hal Å¿ay, I wil attend,

lg.head: Blood.
lg.l: GOod Å¿iÅ¿ters giveme leave (as is my place)

Ile only Å¿hew the wrongs, thou'Å¿t done to me.
Then let my Å¿iÅ¿ters, right their injury.
To pay with railings, is not mine intent,

I will annaliÅ¿e, thy Å¿o proud relation;

Thy childiÅ¿h incongruities, Ile Å¿how:
So walke thee til thou'rt cold, then let thee go.
There is no Souldier, but thy Å¿elfe thou Å¿ay'Å¿t,
No valour upon earth, but what thou haÅ¿t.
Thy fooliÅ¿h provocations, I deÅ¿piÅ¿e.

No pattern, nor no Patron will I bring,
But David, Judah's moÅ¿t heroyick King:
WhoÅ¿e glorious deeds in armes, the world can tel,
A roÅ¿ie cheek'd muÅ¿itian, thou know'Å¿t wel.
He knew how, for to handle, Sword and Harpe,

Thou Å¿ayÅ¿t I love my Å¿word, becauÅ¿e tis guilt:

Thy rudeneÅ¿Å¿e counts, good manners vanity,
And real complements, baÅ¿e flattery.
For drink, which of us twain, like it the beÅ¿t,
Ile go no further then thy noÅ¿e for teÅ¿t.
Thy other Å¿coffes not worthy of reply:
Shal vaniÅ¿h as of no validity.
Of thy black calumnies, this is but part:
But now Ile Å¿hew, what Souldier thou art.
And though thou'Å¿t uÅ¿'d me, with opprobrious Å¿pight,

Thy Choler is but rage, when tis moÅ¿t pure.
But uÅ¿eful, when a mixture can indure.
As with thy mother Fire, Å¿o 'tis with thee,
The beÅ¿t of al the four, when they agree.

Both them and all things elÅ¿e, Å¿he will conÅ¿ume.
Whil'Å¿t us, for thine aÅ¿Å¿ociates thou takeÅ¿t,

WitneÅ¿Å¿e the execrable deeds thou'Å¿t done:

To Å¿atisfie thy pride, and cruelty

Nay Å¿hould I tel, thou wouldÅ¿t count me no blab,

To take the wal's a Å¿in, of Å¿uch high rate,
That naught but blood, the Å¿ame may expiate.
To croÅ¿Å¿e thy wil, a challenge doth deÅ¿erve.
So Å¿pils that life, thou'rt bounden to preÅ¿erve.
Wilt thou this valour, manhood, courage cal:
Nay, know 'tis pride, moÅ¿t diabolical.
If murthers be thy glory, tis no leÅ¿Å¿e.
Ile not envy thy feats, nor happineÅ¿Å¿e.
But if in fitting time, and place, on foes;
For Countries good, thy life thou darÅ¿t expoÅ¿e:
Be dangers neer Å¿o high, and courage great,
Ile praiÅ¿e that fury, valour, choler, heat.
But Å¿uch thou never art, when al alone;
Yet Å¿uch, when we al four are joyn'd in one.
And when Å¿uch thou art, even Å¿uch are we.
The friendly coadjutors, Å¿til to thee.
Nextly, the Å¿pirits thou do'Å¿t wholly claime,
Which natural, vital, animal we name.
To play PhiloÅ¿opher, I have no liÅ¿t;
Nor yet PhiÅ¿itian, nor AnatomiÅ¿t.
For acting theÅ¿e, I have nor wil, nor art,
Yet Å¿hal with equity give thee thy part,
For th' natural, thou doÅ¿t not much conteÅ¿t,
For there are none, thou Å¿ay'Å¿t, if Å¿ome, not beÅ¿t.
That there are Å¿ome, and beÅ¿t, I dare averre;
More uÅ¿eful then the reÅ¿t, don't reaÅ¿on erre;
What is there living, which cannot derive

If thou giv'Å¿t life, I give thee nouriÅ¿hment,

And if vital Å¿pirits do flow from thee,
I am as Å¿ure, the natural from me;

I am the Fountaine which thy CiÅ¿terns fils,

What hath the heart, but what's Å¿ent from the liver?
If thou'rt the taker, I muÅ¿t be the giver:
Then never boaÅ¿t of what thou do'Å¿t receive,
For of Å¿uch glory I Å¿hal thee bereave;
But why the heart, Å¿hould be uÅ¿urpt by thee,
I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿Å¿e, is Å¿omewhat Å¿trange to me,
The Å¿pirits through thy heat, are made perfect there,
But the materials none of thine, that's cleare,
Their wondrous mixture, is of blood, and ayre,
The firÅ¿t my Å¿elf, Å¿econd my Å¿iÅ¿ter faire,
But I'le not force retorts, nor do thee wrong,
Thy fiery yellow froth, is mixt among.
Challenge not all, 'cauÅ¿e part we do allow,
Thou know'Å¿t I've there to do, as wel as thou;
But thou wilt Å¿ay, I deale unequally,
There lives the iraÅ¿cible faculty:
Which without all diÅ¿pute, is Cholers owne;
BeÅ¿ides the vehement heat, only there known,
Can be imputed unto none, but Fire;
Which is thy Å¿elf, thy Mother, and thy Sire;
That this is true, I eaÅ¿ily can aÅ¿Å¿ent,
If Å¿til thou take along my Aliment,

Again, Å¿tomachs concoction thou doÅ¿t claime,
But by what right, nor do'Å¿t, nor canÅ¿t thou name;
It is her own heat, not thy faculty,
Thou do'Å¿t unjuÅ¿tly claime, her property,
The help Å¿he needs, the loving Liver lends,
Who th'benefit o'th' whole ever intends:
To meddle further, I Å¿hal be but Å¿hent,
Th' reÅ¿t to our SiÅ¿ters, is more pertinent.
Your Å¿landers thus refuted, takes no place,
Though caÅ¿t upon my guiltleÅ¿Å¿e bluÅ¿hing face;
Now through your leaves, Å¿ome little time i'le Å¿pend;
My worth in humble manner, to commend.
This hot, moiÅ¿t, nurtritive humour of mine,
When 'tis untaint, pure, and moÅ¿t genuine
Shal firÅ¿tly take her place, as is her due,
Without the leaÅ¿t indignity to you;
Of all your qualities I do partake,
And what you Å¿ingly are, the whole I make.
Your hot, dry, moyÅ¿t, cold, natures are foure,
I moderately am all, what need I more:
As thus, if hot, then dry; if moiÅ¿t, then cold;
If this can't be diÅ¿prov'd, then all I hold:
My vertues hid, i've let you dimly Å¿ee;
My Å¿weet complexion, proves the verity,
This Å¿carlet die's a badge of what's within,
One touch thereof Å¿o beautifies the skin;
Nay, could I be from all your tangs but pure,
Mans life to boundleÅ¿Å¿e time might Å¿til endure;
But here's one thruÅ¿ts her heat, where'ts not requir'd
So Å¿uddenly, the body all is fir'd:
And of the Å¿weet, calme temper, quite bereft,
Which makes the manÅ¿ion, by the Å¿oul Å¿oon left;
So Melancholly ceaÅ¿es on a man;
With her uncheerful viÅ¿age, Å¿warth and wan;
The body dryes, the minde Å¿ublime doth Å¿mother,
And turns him to the wombe of 's earthy mother,
And Flegme like wiÅ¿e can Å¿hew, her cruel art,
With cold diÅ¿tempers, to pain every part;
The Lungs, Å¿he rots, the body weares away,
As if Å¿he'd leave no fleÅ¿h to turn to clay,
Her languiÅ¿hing diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, though not quick,
At length demoliÅ¿hes the faberick,
All to prevent, this curious care I take;
Ith' laÅ¿t concoction, Å¿egregation make.
Of all the perverÅ¿e humours from mine owne,
The bitter choler, moÅ¿t malignant knowne
I turn into his cel, cloÅ¿e by my Å¿ide,
The Melancholly to the Spleen to 'bide;
LikewiÅ¿e the Whey, Å¿ome uÅ¿e I in the veines,
The over plus I Å¿end unto the reines;
But yet for all my toyl, my eare, my skil,
It's doom'd by an irrevocable wil:
That my intents Å¿hould meet with interruption,
That mortal man, might turn to his corruption.
I might here Å¿hew, the nobleneÅ¿Å¿e of minde,
Of Å¿uch as to the Sanguine are inclin'd,
They're liberal, pleaÅ¿ant, kinde, and courteous,
And like the Liver, all benignious;
For Arts, and Sciences, they are the fitteÅ¿t,
And maugre (Choler) Å¿til they are the witteÅ¿t,
An ingenious working phantaÅ¿ie,
A moÅ¿t volumnious large memory,
And nothing wanting but Å¿olidity.
But why, alas, thus tedious Å¿hould I be?
ThouÅ¿and examples, you may daily Å¿ee
If time I have tranÅ¿greÅ¿t, and been too long,
Yet could not be more breif, without much wrong.
I've Å¿carce wip'd off the Å¿pots, proud Choler caÅ¿t,
Such venome lyes in words, though but a blaÅ¿t,
No braggs i've us'd, t'your Å¿elves I dare appeale,
If modeÅ¿ty my worth do not conceale.
I've us'd no bitterneÅ¿Å¿e, nor taxt your name,

lg.head: Melancholy.
lg.l: HE that with two aÅ¿Å¿aylents hath to do,

EÅ¿pecially when freindÅ¿hip is pretended:
That blow's moÅ¿t deadly, where it is intended;

Faire roÅ¿ie SiÅ¿ter, Å¿o might'Å¿t thou Å¿cape free,

And in contentions liÅ¿ts, now juÅ¿tly enter.
Thy boaÅ¿ted valour Å¿toutly's been repell'd,
If not as yet, by me, thou shalt be quell'd:
What mov'd thee thus to villifie my name?
Not paÅ¿t all reaÅ¿on, but in truth all shame:
Thy fiery Å¿pirit Å¿hal bear away this prize,
To play Å¿uch furious pranks I am too wiÅ¿e;
If in a Souldier raÅ¿hneÅ¿Å¿e be Å¿o precious,
Know, in a General its moÅ¿t pernicious.
Nature doth teach, to Å¿heild the head from harm,
The blow that's aim'd thereat is latch'd by th'arm,
When in Battalia my foes I face,
I then command, proud Choler Å¿tand thy place,
To uÅ¿e thy Å¿word, thy courage, and thy Art,
For to defend my Å¿elf, thy better part;
This warineÅ¿Å¿e count not for cowardiÅ¿e,
He is not truly valiant that's not wiÅ¿e;
It's no leÅ¿Å¿e glory to defend a town,
Then by aÅ¿Å¿ault to gain one, not our own.
And if Marcellus bold, be call'd Romes Å¿word,
WiÅ¿e Fabius is her buckler: all accord.
And if thy haÅ¿te, my Å¿lowneÅ¿Å¿e Å¿hould not temper,
'Twere but a mad, irregular diÅ¿temper;
Enough of that, by our SiÅ¿ter heretofore,
I'le come to that which wounds me Å¿omewhat more:
Of Learning, and of Policie, thou would'Å¿t bereave me,
But's not thy ignorance Å¿hal thus deceive me.
What greater Clerke, or polititian lives?
Then he whoÅ¿e brain a touch my humour gives.
What is too hot, my coldneÅ¿Å¿e doth abate;
What's diffluent, I do conÅ¿olidate.
If I be partial judg'd, or thought to erre,
The melancholy Snake Å¿hal it aver.
ThoÅ¿e cold dry heads, more Å¿ubrilly doth yeild,
Then all the huge beaÅ¿ts of the fertile field.
Thirdly, thou doÅ¿t confine me to the Å¿pleen,
As of that only part I was the Queen:
Let me as wel make thy precincts, the gal;
To priÅ¿on thee within that bladder Å¿mal.
Reduce the man to's principles, then Å¿ee
If I have not more part, then al ye three:
What is without, within, of theirs, or thine.
Yet time and age, Å¿hal Å¿oon declare it mine.
When death doth Å¿eize the man, your Å¿tock is loÅ¿t,
When you poor bankrupts prove, then have I moÅ¿t.
You'l Å¿ay, here none Å¿hal ere diÅ¿turbe my right;
You high born (from that lump) then take your flight
Then who's mans friend, when life and all forÅ¿akes?
His mother (mine) him to her wombe retakes,
Thus he is ours, his portion is the grave.
But whilÅ¿t he lives, Ile Å¿hew what part I have.
And firÅ¿t, the firme dry bones, I juÅ¿tly claim:
The Å¿trong foundation of the Å¿tately frame.
LikewiÅ¿e the uÅ¿eful Å¿pleen, though not the beÅ¿t,
Yet is a bowel cal'd wel as the reÅ¿t.
The Liver, Stomach, owes it thanks of right.
The firÅ¿t it draines, o'th' laÅ¿t quicks appetite,
Laughter (though thou Å¿avÅ¿t malice) flowes from hence,
TheÅ¿e two in one cannot have reÅ¿idence.
But thou moÅ¿t groÅ¿ly do'Å¿t miÅ¿take, to thinke
The Spleen for al you three, was made a Å¿inke.
Of al the reÅ¿t, thou'Å¿t nothing there to do;
But if thou haÅ¿t, that malice comes from you.
Again, you often touch my Å¿warthy hew,
That black is black, and I am black, tis true;
But yet more comely far, I dare avow,
Then is thy torrid noÅ¿e, or braÅ¿en brow.
But that which Å¿hewes how high thy Å¿pight is bent,
In charging me, to be thy excrement.
Thy loathÅ¿ome imputation I deÅ¿ie;
So plain a Å¿lander needeth no reply.
When by thy heat, thou'Å¿t bak'd thy Å¿elfe to cruÅ¿t,
Thou do'Å¿t aÅ¿Å¿ume my name, wel be it juÅ¿t;
This tranÅ¿mutation is, but not excretion,
Thou wants PhiloÅ¿ophy, and yet diÅ¿cretion.
Now by your leave, Ile let your greatneÅ¿Å¿e Å¿ee;
What officer thou art to al us three.
The Kitchin Drudge, the cleanÅ¿er of the Å¿inks,
That caÅ¿ts out all that man or eates, or drinks.
Thy bittering quality, Å¿til irretates,
Til filth and thee, nature exhonorates.
If any doubt this truth, whence this Å¿hould come;
Show them thy paÅ¿Å¿age to th' Duodenum.
If there thou'rt Å¿topt, to th' Liver thou turn'Å¿t in,
And Å¿o with jaundiÅ¿e, Safferns al the skin.
No further time ile Å¿pend, in confutations,
I truÅ¿t I've clear'd your Å¿landrous imputations.
I now Å¿peake unto al, no more to one;
Pray hear, admire, and learn inÅ¿truction.
My vertues yours Å¿urpaÅ¿Å¿e, without compare:
The firÅ¿t, my conÅ¿tancy, that jewel rate.
Choler's too raÅ¿h, this golden gift to hold.
And Sanguine is more fickle many fold.
Here, there, her reÅ¿tleÅ¿Å¿e thoughts do ever flye;
ConÅ¿tant in nothing, but inconÅ¿tancy,
And what Flegme is, we know, likewiÅ¿e her mother,
UnÅ¿table is the one, Å¿o is the other.
With me is noble patience alÅ¿o found,
Impatient Choler loveth not the Å¿ound.
VVhat Sanguine is, Å¿he doth not heed, nor care.
Now up, now down, tranÅ¿ported like the Aire.
Flegm's patient, becauÅ¿e her nature's tame.
But I by vertue, do acquire the Å¿ame.
My temperance, chaÅ¿tity, is eminent,
But theÅ¿e with you, are Å¿eldome reÅ¿ident.
Now could I Å¿tain my ruddy Å¿iÅ¿ters face,

Nor are ye free, from this inormity,
Although Å¿he beare the greateÅ¿t obloquie.
My prudence, judgement, now I might reveale,
But wiÅ¿dome 'tis, my wiÅ¿dom to conceale.
Unto diÅ¿eaÅ¿es not inclin'd as ye:
Nor cold, nor hot, Ague, nor PluriÅ¿ie;
Nor Cough, nor QuinÅ¿ie, nor the burning Feavor.
I rarely feel to act his fierce indeavour.
My Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e cheifly in conceit doth lye,
What I imagine, that's my malady.
Strange Chymera's are in my phantaÅ¿ie,
And things that never were, nor Å¿hal I Å¿ee.
Talke I love not, reaÅ¿on lyes not in length.

lg.head: Flegme.
lg.l: PAtient I am, patient i'd need to be,
To bear the injurious taunts of three,
Though wit I want, and anger I have leÅ¿Å¿e,
Enough of both, my wrongs for to expreÅ¿Å¿e;
I've not forgot how bitter Choler Å¿pake,
Nor how her Gaul on me Å¿he cauÅ¿leÅ¿Å¿e brake;
Nor wonder 'twas, for hatred there's not Å¿mal,
Where oppoÅ¿ition is diametrical:
To what is truth, I freely wil aÅ¿Å¿ent,
(Although my name do Å¿uffer derriment)
What's Å¿landerous, repel; doubtful, diÅ¿pute;
And when i've nothing left to Å¿ay, be mute;
Valour I want, no Souldier am, 'tis true,
I'le leave that manly property to you;
I love no thundering Drums, nor bloody Wars,
My poliÅ¿h'd skin was not ordain'd for skars,
And though the pitched field â¢ 've ever fled,
At home, the Conquerours, have conquered:
Nay, I could tel you (what's more true then meet)
That Kings have laid their Scepters at my feet,
When Å¿iÅ¿ter Sanguine paints my Ivory face,
The Monarchs bend, and Å¿ue, but for my grace;
My Lilly white, when joyned with her red,
Princes hath Å¿lav'd, and Captains captived:
Country with Country, Grecce with AÅ¿ia fights,
Sixty nine Princes, all Å¿tout Hero Knights.
Under Troys wals, ten years wil waÅ¿t away,
Rather then looÅ¿e, one beauteous Hellena;
But 'twere as vain, to prove the truth of mine,
As at noon day to tel, the Sun doth Å¿hine.
Next difference betwixt us twain doth lye,
Who doth poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e the Brain, or thou, or I;
Shame forc'd thee Å¿ay, the matter that was mine,
But the Å¿pirits, by which it acts are thine;
Thou Å¿peakeÅ¿t truth, and I can Å¿peak no leÅ¿Å¿e,
Thy heat doth much, I candidly confeÅ¿Å¿e,
But yet thou art as much, I truly Å¿ay,
Beholding unto me another way.
And though I grant, thou art my helper here,
No debtor I, becauÅ¿e 'tis paid elÅ¿e where;
With all your flouriÅ¿hes, now SiÅ¿ters three,
Who is't or dare, or can compare with me;
My excellencies are Å¿o great, Å¿o many,
I am confounded, 'fore I Å¿peak of any:
The Brain's the nobleÅ¿t member all allow,
The Å¿cituation, and form wil it avow,
Its ventricles, membrances, and wond'rous ner,
Galen, Hipocrates, drives to a Å¿et.
That divine EÅ¿Å¿ence, the immortal Soul,
Though it in all, and every part be whole:
Within this Å¿tately place of eminence,
Doth doubtleÅ¿Å¿e keep its mighty reÅ¿idence;
And Å¿urely the Souls Å¿enÅ¿ative here lives,
Which life and motion to each Creature gives,
The conjugations of the parts toth 'brain
Doth shew, hence flowes the power which they retain;
Within this high built Cittadel doth lye,
The ReaÅ¿on, Fancy, and the Memory;
The faculty of Å¿peech doth here abide,
The Å¿pirits animal, from whence doth Å¿lide,
The five moÅ¿t noble Sences, here do dwel,
Of three, its hard to Å¿ay, which doth excel;
This point for to diÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿e longs not to me,
I'le touch the Sight, great'Å¿t wonder of the three;
The optick nerve, coats, humours, all are mine,
Both watry, glaÅ¿Å¿ie, and the chriÅ¿taline.
O! mixture Å¿trange, oh colour, colourleÅ¿Å¿e,
Thy perfect temperament, who can expreÅ¿Å¿e?
He was no foole, who thought the Soul lay here,
Whence her affections, paÅ¿Å¿ions, Å¿peak Å¿o clear;
O! good, O bad, O true, O traiterous eyes!
What wonderments, within your bals there lyes?
Of all the Sences, Sight Å¿hal be the Queen;
Yet Å¿ome may wiÅ¿h, oh, had mine eyes ne're Å¿eene.
Mine likewiÅ¿e is the marrow of the back,
Which runs through all the Å¿pondles of the rack,
It is the Å¿ubÅ¿titute o'th royal Brain,
All nerves (except Å¿even paire) to it retain;
And the Å¿trong ligaments, from hence ariÅ¿e,
With joynt to joynt, the entire body tyes;
Some other parts there iÅ¿Å¿ue from the Brain,
WhoÅ¿e uÅ¿e and worth to tel, I muÅ¿t refrain;
Some worthy learned Crooke may theÅ¿e reveal,
But modeÅ¿ty hath charg'd me to conceal;
Here's my epitome of excellence,
For what's the Brains, is mine, by conÅ¿equence;
A fooliÅ¿h Brain (Å¿aith Choler) wanting heat,
But a mad one, Å¿ay I, where 'tis too great,
PhrenÅ¿ie's worÅ¿e, then folly, one would more glad,
With a tame foole converÅ¿e, then with a mad,
Then, my head for learning is not the fitteÅ¿t,
Ne're did I heare that Choler was the witt'eÅ¿t;
Thy judgement is unÅ¿afe, thy fancy little,
For memory, the Å¿and is not more brittle.
Again, none's fit for Kingly place but thou,
If Tyrants be the beÅ¿t, i'le it allow;
But if love be, as requiÅ¿ite as feare,
Then I, and thou, muÅ¿t make a mixture here:
Wel, to be breif, Choler I hope now's laid,
And I paÅ¿Å¿e by what Å¿iÅ¿ter Sanguine Å¿aid;
To Melancholly i'le make no reply,
The worÅ¿t Å¿he Å¿aid, was, inÅ¿tability,
And too much talk; both which, I do confeÅ¿Å¿e,
A warning good, hereafter i'le Å¿ay leÅ¿Å¿e.
Let's now be freinds, 'tis time our Å¿pight was Å¿pent,
LeÅ¿t we too late, this raÅ¿hneÅ¿Å¿e do repent,
Such premiÅ¿es wil force a Å¿ad concluÅ¿ion,
UnleÅ¿Å¿e we 'gree, all fals into confuÅ¿ion.
Let Sanguine, Choier, with her hot hand hold,
To take her moyÅ¿t, my moiÅ¿tneÅ¿Å¿e wil be bold;
My cold, cold Melanchollies hand Å¿hal claÅ¿p,
Her dry, dry Cholers other hand Å¿hal graÅ¿p;
Two hot, two moiÅ¿t, two cold, two dry here be,
A golden Ring, the PoÅ¿ey, Unity:
Nor jars, nor Å¿coffs, let none hereafter Å¿ee,
But all admire our perfect amity;
Nor be diÅ¿cern'd, here's water, earth, aire, fire,
But here's a compact body, whole, entire:
This loving counÅ¿el pleas'd them all Å¿o wel,
That Flegme was judg'd, for kindneÅ¿Å¿e to excel.

div.head: The Four Ages of Man.

lg.l: LOe now! four other acts upon the Å¿tage,
Childhood, and Youth, the Manly, and Old-age.
The firÅ¿t: Å¿on unto Flegme, grand-child to water,
UnÅ¿table, Å¿upple, moiÅ¿t, and cold's his Naure.
The Å¿econd, frolick, claimes his pedigree,
From blood and aire, for hot, and moiÅ¿t is he.
The third, of fire, and choler is compoÅ¿'d,
Vindicative, and quarelÅ¿ome diÅ¿poÅ¿'d.
The laÅ¿t, of earth, and heavy melancholly,
Solid, hating all lightneÅ¿Å¿e, and al folly.
Childhood was cloath'd in white, and given to Å¿how,
His Å¿pring was intermixed with Å¿ome Å¿now.
Upon his head a Garland Nature Å¿et:
Of Dazy, PrimroÅ¿e, and the Violet.
Such cold mean flowers (as theÅ¿e) bloÅ¿Å¿ome betime,
Before the Sun hath throughly warm'd the clime.
His hobby Å¿triding, did not ride, but run,
And in his hand an hour-glaÅ¿Å¿e new begun,
In dangers every moment of a fall,
And when tis broke, then ends his life and all.
But if he hold, til it have run its laÅ¿t,
Then may he live, til threeÅ¿core years or paÅ¿t.
Next, youth came up, in gorgeous attire;
(As that fond age, doth moÅ¿t of al deÅ¿ire.)
His Suit of CrimÅ¿on, and his Scarfe of Green:
In's countenance, his pride quickly was Å¿een.
Garland of RoÅ¿es, Pinks, and Gilliflowers,
Seemed to grow on's head (bedew'd with Å¿howers:)
His face as freÅ¿h, as is Aurora faire,
When bluÅ¿hing firÅ¿t, Å¿he 'gins to red the Aire.
No wooden horÅ¿e, but one of mettal try'd:
He Å¿eems to flye, or Å¿wim, and not to ride.
Then prauncing on the Stage, about he wheels;
But as he went, death waited at his heeles.
The next came up, in a more graver Å¿ort,
As one that cared, for a good report.
His Sword by's Å¿ide, and choler in his eyes;
But neither us'd (as yet) for he was wiÅ¿e.
Of Autumne fruits a basket on his arme.
His golden god in's purÅ¿e, which was his charm,
And laÅ¿t of al, to act upon this Stage;
Leaning upon his Å¿taffe, comes up old age.
Under his arme a Sheafe of wheat he bore,
A HarveÅ¿t of the beÅ¿t, what needs he more.
In's other hand a glaÅ¿Å¿e, ev'n almoÅ¿t run,
This writ about: This out, then I am done.
His hoary haires, and grave aÅ¿pect made way;
And al gave eare, to what he had to Å¿ay.
TheÅ¿e being met, each in his equipage,
Intend to Å¿peak, according to their age:
But wiÅ¿e Old-age, did with all gravity,
To childiÅ¿h childhood, give precedency.
And to the reÅ¿t, his reaÅ¿on mildly told;
That he was young, before he grew Å¿o old.
To do as he, the reÅ¿t ful Å¿oon aÅ¿Å¿ents,
Their method was, that of the Elements,
That each Å¿hould tel, what of himÅ¿elfe he knew;
Both good and bad, but yet no more then's true.
With heed now Å¿tood, three ages of fraile man;
To hear the child, who crying, thus began.

lg.head: Childhood.
lg.l: AH me! conceiv'd in Å¿in, and born in Å¿orrow,
A nothing, here to day, but gone to morrow.
WhoÅ¿e mean beginning, bluÅ¿hing cann't reveale,
But night and darkeneÅ¿Å¿e, muÅ¿t with Å¿hame conceal.
My mothers breeding Å¿icknes, I will Å¿pare;
Her nine months weary burden not declare.
To Å¿hew her bearing pangs, I Å¿hould do wrong,
To tel that paine, which cann't be told by tongue;
With tears into this world I did arrive;
My mother Å¿til did waÅ¿te, as I did thrive:
Who yet with love, and all alacrity,
Spending was willing, to be Å¿pent for me;
With wayward cryes, I did diÅ¿turbe her reÅ¿t;
Who Å¿ought Å¿til to appeaÅ¿e me, with her breÅ¿t,
With weary armes, Å¿he danc'd, and By, By, Å¿ung,
When wretched I (ungrate) had done the wrong.
When Infancy was paÅ¿t, my ChildiÅ¿hneÅ¿Å¿e,
Did act al folly, that it could expreÅ¿Å¿e.
My Å¿illineÅ¿Å¿e did only take delight,
In that which riper age did Å¿corn, and Å¿light:
In Rattles, Bables, and Å¿uch toyiÅ¿h Å¿tuffe.
My then ambitious thoughts, were low enough.
My high-borne Å¿oule, Å¿o Å¿traitly was confin'd:
That its own worth, it did not know, nor mind.
This little houÅ¿e of fleÅ¿h, did Å¿pacious count:
Through ignorance, all troubles did Å¿urmount.
Yet this advantage, had mine ignorance,
Freedome from Envy, and from Arrogance,
How to be rich, or great, I did not carke;
A Baron or a Duke, ne'r made my mark.
Nor Å¿tudious was, Kings favours how to buy,
With coÅ¿tly preÅ¿ents, or baÅ¿e flattery.
No office coveted, wherein I might
Make Å¿trong my Å¿elfe, and turne aÅ¿ide weak right.
No malice bare, to this, or that great Peer,
Nor unto buzzing whiÅ¿perors, gave ear.
I gave no hand, nor vote, for death, or life:
I'd nought to do, 'twixt Prince, and peoples Å¿trife.
No StatiÅ¿t I: nor Marti'liÅ¿t i' th' field;
Where e're I went, mine innocence was Å¿hield.
My quarrells, not for Diadems did riÅ¿e;
But for an Apple, Plumbe, or Å¿ome Å¿uch prize,
My Å¿troks did cauÅ¿e no death, nor wounds, nor skars.
My little wrath did ceaÅ¿e Å¿oon as my wars.
My duel was no challenge, nor did Å¿eek.
My foe Å¿hould weltering, with his bowels reek.
I had no Suits at law, neighbours to vex.
Nor evidence for land, did me perplex.
I fear'd no Å¿tormes, nor al the windes that blows,
I had no Å¿hips at Sea, no fraughts to looÅ¿e.
I fear'd no drought, nor wet, I had no crop,
Nor yet on future things did place my hope.
This was mine innocence, but oh the Å¿eeds,
Lay raked up; of all the curÅ¿ed weeds,
Which Å¿prouted forth, in my inÅ¿uing age,
As he can tell, that next comes on the Å¿tage.
But yet let me relate, before I go,
The Å¿ins, and dangers I am Å¿ubject to.
From birth Å¿tayned, with Adams Å¿infull fact;
From thence I 'gan to Å¿in, as Å¿oon as act.
A perverÅ¿e will, a love to what's forbid:
A Å¿erpents Å¿ling in pleaÅ¿ing face lay hid.
A lying tongue as Å¿oon as it could Å¿peak,
And fift Commandement do daily break.
Oft Å¿tubborn, peeviÅ¿h, Å¿ullen, pout, and cry:
Then nought can pleaÅ¿e, and yet I know not why.
As many was my Å¿ins, Å¿o dangers too:
For Å¿in brings Å¿orrow, Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e, death, and woe.
And though I miÅ¿Å¿e, the toÅ¿Å¿ings of the mind:
Yet griefs, in my fraile fleÅ¿h, I Å¿till do find.
What gripes of wind, mine infancy did pain?
What tortures I, in breeding teeth Å¿uÅ¿tain?
What crudities my cold Å¿tomach hath bred?
Whence vomits, wormes, and flux have iÅ¿Å¿ued?
What breaches, knocks, and falls I daily have?
And Å¿ome perhaps, I carry to my grave.
Some times in fire, Å¿ometimes in waters fall:
Strangely preÅ¿erv'd, yet mind it not at all.
At home, abroad, my danger's manifold.
That wonder tis, my glaÅ¿Å¿e till now doth hold.
I've done, unto my elders I give way.
For 'tis but little, that a childe can Å¿ay.

lg.head: Youth.
lg.l: MY goodly cloathing, and my beauteous skin,
Declare Å¿ome greater riches are within;
But what is beÅ¿t i'le firÅ¿t preÅ¿ent to view,
And then the worÅ¿t, in a more ugly hue;
For thus to do, we on this Stage aÅ¿Å¿emble,
Then let not him, which hath moÅ¿t craft diÅ¿Å¿emble;
Mine education, and my learning's Å¿uch,
As might my Å¿elf, and others, profit much:
With nurture trained up in vertues Schools,
Of Science, Arts, and Tongues, I know the rules,
The manners of the Court, I likewiÅ¿e know,
Nor ignorant what they in Country do;
The brave attempts of valiant Knights I prize,
That dare climbe Battlements, rear'd to the skies;
The Å¿norting HorÅ¿e, the Trumpet, Drum I like,
The gliÅ¿tring Sword, and wel advanced Pike;
I cannot lye in trench, before a Town,
Nor wait til good advice our hopes do crown;
I Å¿corn the heavy CorÅ¿Å¿et, Musket-proof,
I fly to catch the Bullet that's aloof;
Though thus in field, at home, to all moÅ¿t kind,
So affable that I do Å¿uit each mind;
I can inÅ¿inuate into the breÅ¿t,
And by my mirth can raiÅ¿e the heart depreÅ¿t â¢
Sweet Mufick rapteth my harmonious Soul,
And elevates my thoughts above the Pole.
My wit, my bounty, and my courteÅ¿ie,
Makes all to place their future hopes on me.
This is my beÅ¿t, but youth (is known) alas,
To be as wilde as is the Å¿nuffing AÅ¿Å¿e,
As vain as froth, as vanity can be,
That who would Å¿ee vain man, may look on me:
My gifts abus'd, my education loÅ¿t,
My woful Parents longing hopes all croÅ¿t,
My wit, evaporates in meriment:
My valour, in Å¿ome beaÅ¿tly quarrel's Å¿pent;
Martial deeds I love not, 'cauÅ¿e they're vertuous,
But doing Å¿o, might Å¿eem magnanimous.
My LuÅ¿t doth hurry me, to all that's ill,
I know no Law, nor reaÅ¿on, but my wil;
Sometimes lay wait to take a wealthy purÅ¿e,
Or Å¿tab the man, in's own defence, that's worÅ¿e,
Sometimes I cheat (unkind) a female Heir,
Of all at once, who not Å¿o wiÅ¿e, as fair,
TruÅ¿teth my loving looks, and glozing tongue,
Until her freinds, treaÅ¿ure, and honour's gone.
Sometimes I Å¿it carouÅ¿ing others health,
Until mine own be gone, my wit, and wealth;
From pipe to pot, from pot to words, and blows,
For he that loveth Wine, wanteth no woes;
Dayes, nights, with Ruffins, Roarers, Fidlers Å¿pend;
To all obÅ¿cenity, my eares I bend.
All counÅ¿el hate, which tends to make me wiÅ¿e,
And deareÅ¿t freinds count for mine enemies;
If any care I take, 'tis to be fine,
For Å¿ure my Å¿uit more then my vertues Å¿hine;
If any time from company I Å¿pare,
'Tis Å¿pent in curling, friÅ¿ling up my hair;
Some young Adonis I do Å¿trive to be,
Sardana Pallas, now Å¿urvives in me:
Cards, Dice, and Oaths, concomitant, I love;
To MaÅ¿ques, to Playes, to Taverns Å¿til I move;
And in a word, if what I am you'd heare,
Seek out a BrittiÅ¿h, bruitiÅ¿h Cavaleer;
Such wretch, Å¿uch monÅ¿ter am I; but yet more,
I want a heart all this for to deplore.
Thus, thus alas! I have miÅ¿pent my time,
My youth, my beÅ¿t, my Å¿trength, my bud, and prime:
Remembring not the dreadful day of Doom,
Nor yet that heavy reckoning for to come;
Though dangers do attend me every houre,
And gaÅ¿tly death oft threats me with her power,
Sometimes by wounds in idle combates taken,
Sometimes by Agues all my body Å¿haken;
Sometimes by Feavers, all my moiÅ¿ture drinking,
My heart lyes frying, and my eyes are Å¿inking;
Sometimes the Cough, Stitch, painful Plurifie,
With Å¿ad affrights of death, doth menace me;
Sometimes the loathÅ¿ome Pox, my face be-mars,
With ugly marks of his eternal Å¿cars;
Sometimes the PhrenÅ¿ie, Å¿trangely madds my Brain,
That oft for it, in Bealam I remain.
Too many's my DiÅ¿eaÅ¿es to recite,
That wonder 'tis I yet behold the light,
That yet my bed in darkneÅ¿Å¿e is not made,
And I in black oblivions den long laid;
Of Marrow ful my bones, of Milk my breaÅ¿ts,
Ceas'd by the gripes of Serjeant Death's ArreÅ¿ts:
Thus I have Å¿aid, and what i've Å¿aid you Å¿ee,
