lg.head: Middle Age.
lg.l: CHildehood and youth, forgot, Å¿ometimes I've Å¿een,
And now am grown more Å¿taid, that have beengreen,
What they have done, the Å¿ame was done by me,
As was their praiÅ¿e, or Å¿hame, Å¿o mine muÅ¿t be.
Now age is more, more good ye do expect;
But more my age, the more is my defect.
But what's of worth, your eyes Å¿hal firÅ¿t behold,
And then a world of droÅ¿Å¿e among my gold.
When my Wilde Oates, were Å¿own, and ripe, & mown,
I then receiv'd a harveÅ¿t of mine owne.
My reaÅ¿on, then bad judge, how little hope,
Such empty Å¿eed Å¿hould yeeld a better crop.
I then with both hands, graÅ¿pt the world together,
Thus out of one extreame, into another.
But yet laid hold, on vertue Å¿eemingly,
Who climbes without hold, climbes dangerouÅ¿ly.
Be my condition mean, I then take paines;
My family to keep, but not for gaines.
If rich, I'm urged then to gather more.
To bear me out i'th' world, and feed the poor,
If a father, then for children muÅ¿t provide:
But if none, then for kindred near ally'd.
If Noble, then mine honour to maintaine.
If not, yet wealth, Nobility can gain.
For time, for place, likewiÅ¿e for each relation,
I wanted not my ready allegation.
Yet all my powers, for Å¿elf-ends are not Å¿pent,
For hundreds bleÅ¿Å¿e me, for my bounty Å¿ent.
WhoÅ¿e loynes I've cloth'd, and bellies I have fed;
With mine owne fleece, and with my houÅ¿hold bread.
Yea juÅ¿tice I have done, was I in place;
To chear the good, and wicked to deface.
The proud I cruÅ¿h'd, th' oppreÅ¿Å¿ed I Å¿et free,
The lyars curb'd but nouriÅ¿ht verity.
Was I a paÅ¿tor, I my flock did feed:
And gently lead the lambes, as they had need,
A Captain I, with skil I train'd my band;
And Å¿hew'd them how, in face of foes to Å¿tand.
If a Souldier, with Å¿peed I did obey,
As readily as could my Leader Å¿ay:
Was I a laborer, I wrought all day,
As chearfully as ere I took my pay.
Thus hath mine age (in all) Å¿ometimes done wel.
Sometimes mine age (in all) been worÅ¿e then hell.
In meanneÅ¿Å¿e, greatneÅ¿Å¿e, riches, poverty;
Did toile, did broile; oppreÅ¿Å¿'d, did Å¿teal and lye.
Was I as poor, as poverty could be,
Then baÅ¿eneÅ¿Å¿e was companion unto me.
Such Å¿cum, as Hedges, and High-wayes do yeeld,
As neither Å¿ow, nor reape, nor plant, nor build.
If to Agricolture, I was ordain'd.
Great labours, Å¿orrows, croÅ¿Å¿es I Å¿uÅ¿tain'd
The early Cock, did Å¿ummon but in vaine,
My wakefull thoughts, up to my painefull gaine.
For reÅ¿tleÅ¿Å¿e day and night, I'm rob'd of Å¿teep,
By can kered care, who centinel doth keep.
My weary beaÅ¿t, reÅ¿t from his toile can find;
But if I reÅ¿t, the more diÅ¿treÅ¿t my mind.
If happineÅ¿Å¿e my Å¿ordidneÅ¿Å¿e hath found,
'Twas in the crop of my manured ground:
My fatted Oxe, and my exuberous Cow,
My fleeced Ewe, and ever farr owing Sow.
To greater things, I never did aÅ¿pire,
My dunghil thoughts, or hopes, could reach no higher.
If to be rich, or great, it was my fate;
How was I broyl'd with envy, and with hate?
Greater, then was the great'Å¿t, was my deÅ¿ire,
And greater Å¿til, did Å¿et my heart on fire.
If honour was the point, to which I Å¿teer'd;
To run my hull upon diÅ¿grace I fear'd.
But by ambitious Å¿ailes, I was Å¿o carryed;
That over flats, and Å¿ands, and rocks I hurried,
OppreÅ¿t, and Å¿unke, and Å¿act, all in my way;
That did oppoÅ¿e me, to my longed bay:
My thirÅ¿t was higher, then Nobility.
And oft long'd Å¿ore, to taÅ¿te on Royalty.
Whence poyÅ¿on, PiÅ¿tols, and dread inÅ¿truments,
Have been curÅ¿t furtherers of mine intents.
Nor Brothers, Nephewes, Sons, nor Sires I've Å¿par'd.
When to a Monarchy, my way they barr'd.
There Å¿et, I rid my Å¿elfe Å¿traight out of hand.
Of Å¿uch as might my Å¿on, or his withÅ¿tand.
Then heapt up gold, and riches as the clay;
Which others Å¿catter, like the dew in May.
Sometimes vaine-glory is the only bait,
Whereby my empty Å¿oule, is lur'd and caught.
Be I of worth, of learning, or of parts;
I judge, I Å¿hould have room, in all mens hearts.
And envy gnawes, if any do Å¿urmount.
I hate for to be had, in Å¿mall account.
If Bias like, I'm Å¿tript unto my skin,
I glory in my wealth, I have within.
Thus good, and bad, and what I am, you Å¿ee,
Now in a word, what my diÅ¿eaÅ¿es be.
The vexing Stone, in bladder and in reines,
Torments me with intollerable paines;
The windy Cholick oft my bowels rend,
To break the darkÅ¿ome priÅ¿on, where it's pend;
The knotty Gout doth Å¿adly torture me,
And the reÅ¿training lame Sciatica;
The QuinÅ¿ie, and the Feavours, oft diÅ¿taÅ¿te me,
And the ConÅ¿umption, to the bones doth waÅ¿t me;
Subject to all DiÅ¿eaÅ¿es, that's the truth,
Though Å¿ome more incident to age, or youth:
And to conclude, I may not tedious be,
Man at his beÅ¿t eÅ¿tate is vanity.

lg.head: Old Age.
lg.l: WHat you have been, ev'n Å¿uch have I before,
And all you Å¿ay, Å¿ay I, and Å¿omething more;
Babes innocence, Youths wildnes I have Å¿een.
And in perplexed Middle-age have bin,
SickneÅ¿Å¿e, dangers, and anxieties have paÅ¿t,
And on this Stage am come to act my laÅ¿t:
I have bin young, and Å¿trong, and wiÅ¿e as you,
But now, Bis pueri Å¿enes, is too true;
In every Age i've found much vanitie,
An end of all perfection now I Å¿ee.
It's not my valour, honour, nor my gold,
My ruin'd houÅ¿e, now falling can uphold;
It's not my Learning, Rhetorick, wit Å¿o large,
Now hath the power, Deaths Warfare, to diÅ¿charge;
It's not my goodly houÅ¿e, nor bed of down,
That can refreÅ¿h, or eaÅ¿e, if ConÅ¿cience frown;
Nor from alliance now can I have hope,
But what I have done wel, that is my prop;
He that in youth is godly, wiÅ¿e, and Å¿age,
Provides a Å¿taffe for to Å¿upport his age.
Great mutations, Å¿ome joyful, and Å¿ome Å¿ad,
In this Å¿hort Pilgrimage I oft have had;
Sometimes the Heavens with plenty Å¿mil'd on me,
Sometimes again, rain'd all adverÅ¿ity;
Sometimes in honour, Å¿ometimes in diÅ¿grace,
Sometime an abject, then again in place,
Such private changes oft mine eyes have Å¿een,
In various times of Å¿tate i've alÅ¿o been.
I've Å¿een a Kingdom flouriÅ¿h like a tree,
When it was rul'd by that CeleÅ¿tial Å¿he;
And like a Cedar, others Å¿o Å¿urmount,
That but for Å¿hrubs they did themÅ¿elves account;
Then Å¿aw I France, and Holland Å¿av'd, Cales won,
And Philip, and Albertus, half undone;
I Å¿aw all peace at home, terror to foes,
But ah, I Å¿aw at laÅ¿t thoÅ¿e eyes to cloÅ¿e:
And then, me thought, the world at noon grew dark,
When it had loÅ¿t that radiant Sun-like Å¿park,
In midÅ¿t of greifs, I Å¿aw Å¿ome hopes revive,
(For 'twas our hopes then kept our hearts alive)
I Å¿aw hopes daÅ¿ht, our forwardneÅ¿Å¿e was Å¿hent,
And Å¿ilenc'd we, by Act of Parliament.
I've Å¿een from Rome, an execra â¢ le thing,
A plot to blow up Nobles, and their King;
I've Å¿een deÅ¿ignes at Ree, and Cades croÅ¿t,
And poor Palatinate for ever loÅ¿t;
I've Å¿een a Prince, to live on others lands,
A Royall one, by almes from Subjects hands,
I've Å¿een baÅ¿e men, advanc'd to great degree,
And worthy ones, put to extremity:
But not their Princes love, nor Å¿tate Å¿o high;
could once reverÅ¿e, their Å¿hamefull deÅ¿tiny.
I've Å¿een one Å¿tab'd, another looÅ¿e his head;
And others fly their Country, through their dread.
I've Å¿een, and Å¿o have ye, for 'tis but late,
The deÅ¿olation, of a goodly State.
Plotted and acted, Å¿o that none can tell,
Who gave the counÅ¿el, but the Prince of hell.
I've Å¿een a land unmoulded with great paine.
But yet may live, to Å¿ee't made up again:
I've Å¿een it Å¿haken, rent, and Å¿oak'd in blood,
But out of troubles, ye may Å¿ee much good,
TheÅ¿e are no old wives tales, but this is truth;
We old men love to tell, what's done in youth.
But I returne, from whence I Å¿tept awry,
My memory is Å¿hort, and braine is dry.
My Almond-tree (gray haires) doth flouriÅ¿h now,
And back, once Å¿traight, begins apace to bow.
My grinders now are few, my Å¿ight doth faile
My skin is wrinkled, and my cheeks are pale.
No more rejoyce, at muÅ¿ickes pleaÅ¿ant noyÅ¿e,
But do awake, at the cocks clanging voyce.
I cannot Å¿cent, Å¿avours of pleaÅ¿ant meat,
Nor Å¿apors find, in what I drink or eat.
My hands and armes, once Å¿trong have loÅ¿t their might,
I cannot labour, nor I cannot fight:
My comely legs, as nimble as the Roe,
Now Å¿tiffe and numb, can hardly creep or go.
My heart Å¿ometimes as fierce, as Lion bold,
Now trembling, and fearful, Å¿ad, and cold;
My golden Bowl, and Å¿ilver Cord, e're long,
Shal both be broke, by wracking death Å¿o Å¿trong;
I then Å¿hal go, whence I Å¿hal come no more,
Sons, Nephews, leave, my death for to deplore;
In pleaÅ¿ures, and in labours, I have found.
That earth can give no conÅ¿olation Å¿ound.
To great, to rich, to poore, to young, or old,
To mean, to noble, fearful, or to bold:
From King to begger, all degrees Å¿hal finde
But vanity, vexation of the minde;
Yea knowing much, the pleaÅ¿ant'Å¿t life of all,
Hath yet amongÅ¿t that Å¿weet, Å¿ome bitter gall.
Though reading others Works, doth much refreÅ¿h,
Yet Å¿tudying much, brings wearineÅ¿Å¿e to th' fleÅ¿h;
My Å¿tudies, labours, readings, all are done,
And my laÅ¿t period now e'n almoÅ¿t run;
Corruption. my Father, I do call,
Mother, and Å¿iÅ¿ters both; the worms, that crawl,
In my dark houÅ¿e, Å¿uch kindred I have Å¿tore,
There, I Å¿hal reÅ¿t, til heavens Å¿hal be no more;
And when this fleÅ¿h Å¿hal rot, and be conÅ¿um'd,
This body, by this Å¿oul, Å¿hal be aÅ¿Å¿um'd;
And I Å¿hal Å¿ee, with theÅ¿e Å¿ame very eyes,
My Å¿trong Redeemer, comming in the skies;
Triumph I Å¿hal, o're Sin, o're Death, o're Hel,
And in that hope, I bid you all farewel.

div.head: The four SeaÅ¿ons of the Yeare.

lg.head: Spring.
lg.l: ANother Four i've yet for to bring on,
Of four times four, the laÅ¿t quaternian;
The Winter, Summer, Autumne, and the Spring,
In Å¿eaÅ¿on all theÅ¿e SeaÅ¿ons I Å¿hal bring;
Sweet Spring, like man in his minority,
At preÅ¿ent claim'd, and had priority,
With Å¿miling Sun-Å¿hine face, and garments green,
She gently thus began, like Å¿ome fair Queen;
Three months there are allotted to my Å¿hare,
March, April, May, of all the reÅ¿t moÅ¿t faire;
The tenth o'th' firÅ¿t Sol into Aries enters,
And bids defiance to all tedious Winters:
And now makes glad thoÅ¿e blinded Northern wights,
Who for Å¿ome months have Å¿een out Å¿tarry lights,
CroÅ¿Å¿es the Line, and equals night and day,
Stil adds to th' laÅ¿t, til after pleaÅ¿ant May;
Now goes the Plow-man to his merry toyl,
For to unlooÅ¿e his Winter-locked Å¿oyl;
The SeedÅ¿-man now doth laviÅ¿h out his Grain,
In hope, the more he caÅ¿ts, the more to gain;
The Gardner, now Å¿uperfluous branches l â¢ ps,
And Poles erects, for his green clambering Hops;
Now digs, then Å¿ows, his hearbs, his flowers, and â¢ oots,
And carefully manures his trees of fruits.
The Pleiades, their influence now give,
And all that Å¿eem'd as dead, afreÅ¿h do live.
The croaking Frogs, whom nipping Winter kild,
Like Birds, now chirp, and hop about the field,
The Nitingale, the Black-bird, and the ThruÅ¿h,
Now tune their layes, on Å¿prays of every buÅ¿h;
The wanton frisking Kids, and Å¿oft fleec'd Lambs,
Now jump, and play, before their feeding Dams,
The tender tops of budding GraÅ¿Å¿e they crop,
They joy in what they have, but more in hope,
For though the FroÅ¿t hath loÅ¿t his binding power,
Yet many a fleece of Snow, and Å¿tormy Å¿howre,
Doth darken Sols bright face, makes us remember
The pinching Nor-weÅ¿t cold, of fierce December.
My Å¿econd month is April, green, and fair,
Of longer dayes, and a more temperate air;
The Sun now keeps his poÅ¿ting reÅ¿idence
In Taurus Signe, yet haÅ¿teth Å¿traight from thence;
For though in's running progreÅ¿Å¿e he doth take
Twelve houÅ¿es of the oblique Zodiack,
Yet never minute Å¿til was known to Å¿tand,
But only once at JoÅ¿hua's Å¿trange command;
This is the month whoÅ¿e fruitfull Å¿howers produces
All Plants, and Flowers, for all delights, and uÅ¿es;
The Pear, the Plumbs, and Apple-tree now flouriÅ¿h,
And GraÅ¿Å¿e growes long, the tender Lambs to nouriÅ¿h;
The PrimroÅ¿e pale, and azure Violet,
Among the verduous GraÅ¿Å¿e hath Nature Å¿et,
That when the Sun (on's love) the earth doth Å¿hine,
TheÅ¿e might as Lace, Å¿et out her Garments fine;
The fearful Bird, his little houÅ¿e now builds,
In trees, and wals, in cities, and in fields,
The outÅ¿ide Å¿trong, the inÅ¿ide warme and near.
A natural Artificer compleate.
The clocking hen, her chipping brood now leads,
With wings, and beak, defends them from the gleads.
My next, and laÅ¿t, is pleaÅ¿ant fruitfull May,
Wherein the earth, is clad in rich aray:
The Å¿un now enters, loving Geminie,
And heats us with, the glances of his eye,
Our Winter rayment, makes us lay aÅ¿ide,
LeaÅ¿t by his fervor, we be terrifi'd,
All flowers before the Å¿un-beames now diÅ¿cloÅ¿es,
Except the double Pinks, and matchleÅ¿Å¿e RoÅ¿es.
Now Å¿warmes the buÅ¿ie buzzing hony Bee.
WhoÅ¿e praiÅ¿e deÅ¿erves a page, from more then me.
The cleanly huÅ¿wives D â¢ ry, now's ith' prime,,
Her Å¿helves, and Firkins fill'd for winter time.
The Meads with CowÅ¿lip, Hony-Å¿uckl's dight,
One hangs his head, the other Å¿tands upright:
But both rejoyce, at th'heavens clear Å¿miling face,
More at her Å¿howers, which water them a Å¿pace.
For fruits, my Å¿eaÅ¿on yeelds, the early Cherry,
The haÅ¿ty PeaÅ¿e, and wholeÅ¿ome red Strawberry,
More Å¿olid fruits, require a longer time.
Each Å¿eaÅ¿on, hath his fruit, Å¿o hath each clime.
Each man his owne peculiar excellence,
But none in all that hath preheminence.
Some Å¿ubject, Å¿hallow braines, much matter yeelds,
Sometime a theame that's large, proves barren fields.
Melodious Spring, with thy Å¿hort pittance flye,
In this harÅ¿h Å¿train, I find no melody,
Yet above all, this priviledge is th â¢ ne,
Thy dayes Å¿til lengthen, without leaÅ¿t decline.

lg.head: Summer.
lg.l: WHen Spring had done, then Summer muÅ¿t begin,
With melted tauny face, and garments thinne.
ReÅ¿embling choler, fite and middle-age;
As Spring did aire, blood, youth in's equipage.
Wiping her Å¿weat from off her brow, that ran,
VVith haire all wet, Å¿he puffing thus began.
Bright June, July, and AuguÅ¿t, hot are mine,
Ith' firÅ¿t, Sol doth in crabed Cancer Å¿hine.
His progreÅ¿Å¿e to the North; now's fully done,
And retrograde, now is my burning Sun.
VVho to his Southward tropick Å¿till is bent,
Yet doth his parching heat the more augment,
The reaÅ¿on why, becauÅ¿e his flames Å¿o faire,
Hath formerly much heat, the earth and aire.
Like as an oven, that long time hath been heat.
WhoÅ¿e vehemency, at length doth grow Å¿o great,
That if you do, remove her burning Å¿tore,
She's for a time as fervent as before.
Now go thoÅ¿e frolick Å¿waines, the Å¿hepheard lad,
To waÅ¿h their thick cloath'd flocks, with pipes ful glad.
In the coole Å¿treames they labour with delight,
Rubbing their dirty coates, till they look white.
WhoÅ¿e fleece when purely Å¿pun, and deeply dy'd,
With robes thereof, Kings have been dignifi'd.
'MongÅ¿t all ye Å¿hepheards, never but one man,
Was like th â¢ t noble, brave Archadian.
Yet hath your life, made Kings the Å¿ame envy,
Though you rep â¢ Å¿e on graÅ¿Å¿e under the skye.
CareleÅ¿Å¿e of worldly wealth, you Å¿it and pipe,
WhilÅ¿t they're imbroyl'd in Wars, and troubles ripe;
Which made great Bajazet cry out in's woes,
Oh! happy Shepheard, which had not to loÅ¿e.
Orthobulus, nor yet SebaÅ¿tia great,
But whiÅ¿t'leth to thy Flock in cold, and heat,
Viewing the Sun by day, the Moon by night,
Endimions, Diana's dear delight;
This Month the RoÅ¿es are diÅ¿till'd in GlaÅ¿Å¿es,
WhoÅ¿e fragrant Å¿cent, all made-perfume Å¿urpaÅ¿Å¿es;
The Cherry, GooÅ¿-berry, is now i'th prime,
And for all Å¿orts of PeaÅ¿e this is the time.
July my next, the hot'Å¿t in all the year,
The Sun in Leo now hath his carrear,
WhoÅ¿e flaming breath doth melt us from afar,
IncreaÅ¿ed by the Star Canicular;
This month from Julius CaeÅ¿ar took the name,
By Romans celebrated to his fame.
Now go the Mowers to their Å¿laÅ¿hing toyl,
The Medows of their burden to diÅ¿poyl;
With weary Å¿troaks, they take all in their way,
Bearing the burning heat of the long day;
The Forks, and Rakes do follow them amain,
Which makes the aged fields look young again,
The groaning Carts to bear away this priÅ¿e.
To Barns, and Stacks, where it for Fodder lyes.
My next, and laÅ¿t, is AuguÅ¿t, fiery hot,
For yet the South-ward Sun abateth not;
This month he keeps with Virgo for a Å¿pace,
The dryed earth is parched by his face.
August, of great AuguÅ¿tus took its name,
Romes Å¿econd Emperour of peaceful fame;
With Sickles now, the painful Reapers go,
The ruffling treÅ¿Å¿e of terra for to moe,
And bundles up in Å¿heaves the weighty Wheat,
Which after Manchet's made, for Kings to eat;
The Barley, and the Rye, Å¿hould firÅ¿t had place,
Although their Bread have not Å¿o white a face.
The Carter leads all home, with whiÅ¿tling voyce,
He plow'd with pain, but reaping doth rejoyce;
His Å¿weat, his toyl, his careful, wakeful nights,
His fruitful crop, abundantly requites.
Now's ripe the Pear, Pear-plumbe, and Apricock,
The Prince of Plumbs, whoÅ¿e Å¿tone is hard as Rock.
The Summer's Å¿hort, the beauteous Autumne haÅ¿tes,
To Å¿hake his fruit, of moÅ¿t delicious taÅ¿tes;
Like good Old Age, whoÅ¿e younger juycie roots,
Hath Å¿til aÅ¿cended up in goodly Fruits,
Until his head be gray, and Å¿trength be gone,
Yet then appears the worthy deeds he 'ath done:
To feed his boughes, exhauÅ¿ted hath his Å¿ap,
Then drops his Fruits into the Eaters lap.

lg.head: Autumne.
lg.l: OF Autumne months, September is the prime,
Now day and night are equal in each clime;
The tenth of this, Sol riÅ¿eth in the Line,
And doth in poyzing Libra this month Å¿hine.
The Vintage now is ripe, the Grapes are preÅ¿t,
WhoÅ¿e lively liquor oft is curÅ¿t, and bleÅ¿t;
For nought's Å¿o good, but it may be abuÅ¿ed,
But its a precious juyce, when wel it's uÅ¿ed.
The RaiÅ¿ins now in cluÅ¿ters dryed be,
The Orange, Lemon, Dangle on the tree;
The Figge is ripe, the Pomgranet alÅ¿o,
And Apples now their yellow Å¿ides do Å¿how;
Of Medlar, Quince, of Warden, and of Peach,
The Å¿eaÅ¿on's now at hand, of all, and each;
Sure at this time, Time firÅ¿t of all began,
And in this month was made apoÅ¿tate man;
For then in Eden was not only Å¿een
Boughs full of leaves, or fruits, but raw, and green,
Or withered Å¿tocks, all dry, and dead,
But trees with goodly fruits repleniÅ¿hed;
Which Å¿hewes, nor Summer, Winter, nor the Spring,
Great Adam was of Paradice made King.
October is my next, we heare in this,
The Northern Winter blaÅ¿ts begin to hiÅ¿Å¿e;
In Scorpio reÅ¿ideth now the Sun,
And his declining heat is almoÅ¿t done.
The fruitful trees, all withered now do Å¿tand,
WhoÅ¿e yellow Å¿apleÅ¿Å¿e leaves by winds are fann'd:
Which notes, when youth, and Å¿trength, have paÅ¿t their prime,
Decrepit age muÅ¿t alÅ¿o have its time;
The Å¿ap doth Å¿lily creep towards the earth,
There reÅ¿ts, untill the Sun give it a birth:
So doth Old Age Å¿til tend unto his Grave,
Where alÅ¿o he, his Winter time muÅ¿t have;
But when the Son of RighteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e drawes nigh,
His dead old Å¿tock, again Å¿hall mount on high.
November is my laÅ¿t, for time doth haÅ¿te,
We now of Winters Å¿harpneÅ¿Å¿e 'gin to taÅ¿te;
This month's the Sun in Sagitarius,
So farre remote, his glances warm not us;
AlmoÅ¿t at Å¿horteÅ¿t is the Å¿hortned day,
The Northern Pole beholdeth not one ray.
Now Green-land, Groen-land, Lap-land, Fin-land, Å¿ee
No Sun, to lighten their obÅ¿curity;
Poor wretches, that in total darkneÅ¿Å¿e lye,
With minds more dark, then is the darkned sky;
This month is timber for all uÅ¿es fell'd,
When cold, the Å¿ap to th' roots hath low'Å¿t repell'd;
Beef, Brawn, and Pork, are now in great'Å¿t requeÅ¿t,
And Å¿olid'Å¿t meats, our Å¿tomachs can digeÅ¿t;
This time warm cloaths, ful diet, and good fires,
Our pinched fleÅ¿h, and empty panch requires:
Old cold, dry age, and earth, Autumne reÅ¿embles,
And melancholy, which moÅ¿t of all diÅ¿Å¿embles.
I muÅ¿t be Å¿hort, and Å¿hort's, the Å¿hortned day,
What Winter hath to tel, now let him Å¿ay.

lg.head: Winter.
lg.l: COld, moiÅ¿t, young, flegmy Winter now doth lye
In Swadling clouts, like new-born infancy,
Bound up with FroÅ¿ts, and fur â¢ 'd with HaiÅ¿s, and Snows,
And like an Infant, Å¿til he taller growes.
December is the firÅ¿t, and now the Sun
To th' Southward tropick his Å¿wift race hath run;
This month he's hous'd in horned Capricorn,
From thence he 'gins to length the Å¿hortned morn,
Through ChriÅ¿tendome, with great feÅ¿tivity
Now's held, a GueÅ¿t, (but bleÅ¿t) Nativity.
Cold frozen January next comes in,
Chilling the blood, and Å¿hrinking up the skin.
In Aquarias, now keeps the loved Sun,
And North-ward his unwearied race doth run;
The day much longer then it was before,
The cold not leÅ¿Å¿ened, but augmented more.
Now toes, and eares, and fingers often freeze,
And Travellers Å¿ometimes their noÅ¿es leeÅ¿e.
MoyÅ¿t Å¿nowie February is my laÅ¿t,
I care not how the Winter time doth haÅ¿te;
In PiÅ¿ces now the golden Sun doth Å¿hine,
And North-ward Å¿til approaches to the Line;
The Rivers now do ope, and Snows do melt,
And Å¿ome warm glances from the Sun are felt,
Which is increaÅ¿ed by the lengthened day,
Until by's heat he drives all cold away.

l.hi: My Subjects bare, my Brains are bad,
Or better Lines you Å¿hould have had;

div.head: The Foure Monarchies,
the AÅ¿Å¿yrian being the firÅ¿t, beginning under Nimrod, 131. yeares after the Floud.

lg.l: WHen Time was young, and World in infancy,
Man did not Å¿trive for Soveraignty,

This was the Golden Age, but after came,
The boyÅ¿terous Sons of CuÅ¿h, Grand-child to Ham.
That mighty Hunter, who in his Å¿trong toyls,
Both BeaÅ¿ts and Men Å¿ubjected to his Å¿poyls.

TheÅ¿e were his firÅ¿t, all Å¿tood in Shinar land,

lg.head: Bellus.
lg.l: GReat Nimrod dead, Bellus the next, his Son,

lg.head: Ninus.
lg.l: HIs father dead, Ninus begins his reign,

The walls one hundred Å¿ixty foot upright,

This Ninus for a god, his father canoniz'd,
To whom the Å¿ottiÅ¿h people Å¿acrific'd;
This Tyrant did his neighbours all oppreÅ¿Å¿e,
Where e're he warr'd he had too good Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e,
Barzanes, the great Armenian King,
By force, his tributary, he did bring.
The Median country, he did alÅ¿o gain,
Pharmus, their King, he cauÅ¿ed to be Å¿lain;

lg.head: Semiramis.
lg.l: THis great oppreÅ¿Å¿ing Ninus dead, and gone,
His wife, Semiramis, uÅ¿urp'd the throne,

And was both Å¿hame, and glory of her Å¿ex;
Her birth-place was PhiliÅ¿trius AÅ¿calon,
Her Mother Docreta, a Curtezan;
Others report, Å¿he was a veÅ¿tal Nun,
Adjudged to be drown'd, for what Å¿he'd done;

Her beautious face (they feign) retaining Å¿till.
Sure from this fiction, Dagon firÅ¿t began,

But all agree, that from no lawfull bed;
This great renowned EmpreÅ¿Å¿e, iÅ¿Å¿ued.
For which, Å¿he was obÅ¿curely nouriÅ¿hed.
Whence roÅ¿e that fable, Å¿he by birds was fed.
This gallant dame, unto the Bactrian war;
Accompaning her husband Menon far,
Taking a towne, Å¿uch valour Å¿he did Å¿how,
That Ninus of her, amorous Å¿oon did grow;
And thought her fit, to make a Monarch's wife,
Which was the cauÅ¿e, poor Menon loÅ¿t his life,
She flouriÅ¿hing with Ninus, long did reigne;
Till her ambition, caus'd him to be Å¿laine:
That having no compeer, Å¿he might rule all,
Or elÅ¿e Å¿he Å¿ought, revenge for Menons fall:
Some think the Greeks, this Å¿lander on her caÅ¿t,
As of her life, licenti â¢â¢ s, and unchaÅ¿t.

With Tow â¢â¢ s, and Bulwalks made of coÅ¿tly Å¿tone
Quadrangle was the forme, it â¢ ood upon:
Each Square, was ãâã thouÅ¿and paces long,

Three hundred Å¿ixty foot, the walls in heighth:

With great facility, march Å¿afe upon't.
About the wall, a ditch Å¿o deep and wide,

Three hundred thouÅ¿and men, here day, by day;
BeÅ¿tow'd their labour, and receiv'd their pay,
But that which did, all coÅ¿t, and art excell,
The wondrous Temple was, Å¿he rear'd to Bell;

This to diÅ¿cribe, in each particular,

Her gardens, bridges, arches, mounts, and Å¿pires;

On Shinar plain, by the Euphratan flood,

An expedition to the EaÅ¿t Å¿he made.
Great King Staurobates, for to invade.
Her Army of four Millions did conÅ¿iÅ¿t,
(Each man beleive it, as his fancy liÅ¿t)
Her Camells, Chariots, Gallyes in Å¿uch number,

But this is marvelous, of all thoÅ¿e men,

This was laÅ¿t progreÅ¿Å¿e of this mighty Queen,

Forty two years Å¿he reign'd, and then Å¿he dy'd,

lg.head: Ninias, or Zamies.
lg.l: HIs Mother dead, Ninias obtains his right,
A Prince wedded to eaÅ¿e, and to delight,
Or elÅ¿e was his obedience very great,
To Å¿it, thus long (obÅ¿cure) wrong'd of his Å¿eat;

Which made the people think they Å¿erv'd her Son;
But much it is, in more then forty years,
This fraud, in war, nor peace, at all appears;
It is more like, being with pleaÅ¿ures fed,
He Å¿ought no rule, til Å¿he was gone, and dead?
What then he did, of worth, can no man tel,
But is Å¿uppos'd to be that Amraphel,
Who warr'd with Sodoms, and Gomorahs King,
'GainÅ¿t whom his trained Bands Abram did bring.
Some may object, his Parents ruling all,
How he thus Å¿uddenly Å¿hould be thus Å¿mall?
This anÅ¿wer may Å¿uffice, whom it wil pleaÅ¿e,
He thus voluptuous, and given to eaÅ¿e;
Each wronged Prince, or childe that did remain,
Would now advantage take, their own to gain;
So Province, after Province, rent away,
Until that potent Empire did decay.
Again, the Country was left bare (there is no doubt)
Of men, and wealth, his mother carried out;
Which to her neighbours, when it was made known,
Did then incite, them to regain their own.
What e're he was, they did, or how it fel,

And told, how Solon in his hight had Å¿poke.
With pitty Cyrus mov'd, knowing Kings Å¿tand,
Now up, now down, as fortune turnes her hand,
Weighing the age, and greatneÅ¿Å¿e of the Prince,
(His Mothers Vnckle, Å¿tories doe evince:)

And with the Lidians, had no more to doe.
Next war, the reÅ¿tleÅ¿Å¿e Cyrus thought upon,

Was conqueÅ¿t of the Å¿tately
â¢ abylon,
Now trebble wall'd, and moated Å¿o about,

Not finding a defendant thereupon;

Upon earths richeÅ¿t Å¿poyles his Souldiers preys;
Here twenty yeares proviÅ¿ion he found,
Forty five mile this City Å¿carce could round;

Had after thouÅ¿and yeares faire to be Å¿een.
Cyrus doth now the JewiÅ¿h captives free,

Long after this, he 'gainÅ¿t the Sythians goes,

Which to revenge, Å¿he hires a mighty power,
And Å¿ets on Cyrus, in a fatall houre;
There routs his HoaÅ¿t, himÅ¿elf Å¿he priÅ¿oner takes,
And at one blow, worlds head, Å¿he headleÅ¿Å¿e makes;

UÅ¿ing Å¿uch taunting words as Å¿he thought good.
But Zenophon reports, he dy'd in's bed,

And in his Town of PaÅ¿argada lyes,

But in this Tombe was only to be found
Two Sythian bowes, a Å¿word, and target round;
Where that proud Conquerour could doe no leÅ¿Å¿e,
Then at his HerÅ¿e great honours to expreÅ¿Å¿e;

lg.head: CambyÅ¿es.
lg.l: CAmbyÅ¿es, no wayes like, his noble Sire,
But to enlarge his Å¿tate, had Å¿ome deÅ¿ire;
His reign with Bloud, and InceÅ¿t, firÅ¿t begins;
Then Å¿ends to finde a Law for theÅ¿e his Å¿ins;
That Kings with SiÅ¿ters match, no Law they finde,
But that the PerÅ¿ian King, may act his minde;
Which Law includes all Lawes, though lawleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿til,
And makes it lawful Law, if he but wil;
He wages warre, the fifth year of his reign,
'GainÅ¿t Aegypts King, who there by him was Å¿lain,
And all of Royal bloud that came to hand,
He Å¿eized firÅ¿t of life, and then of Land;
(But little Marus, Å¿cap'd that cruel fate,
Who grown a man, reÅ¿um'd again his Å¿tate)
He next to Cyprus Å¿ends his bloudy HoaÅ¿t,
Who landed Å¿oon upon that fruitful coaÅ¿t,
Made Evelthon their King, with bended knee,
To hold his own, of his free courteÅ¿ie;
The Temples he deÅ¿troyes not, for his zeal,
But he would be profeÅ¿t god of their Weal;
Yea, in his pride, he ventured Å¿o farre,
To Å¿poyl the Temple of great Jupiter;
But as they marched o're thoÅ¿e deÅ¿art Å¿ands,
The Å¿tormed duÅ¿t o'r-whelm'd his daring bands;
But Å¿corning thus by Jove to be out-brav'd,
A Å¿econd Army there had almoÅ¿t grav'd;
But vain he found, to fight with Elements,
So left his Å¿acrilegious bold intents:
The Aegyptian Apis then he likewiÅ¿e Å¿lew,
Laughing to Å¿corn that calviÅ¿h, Å¿ottiÅ¿h crew.
If all his heat, had been for a good end,
CambyÅ¿es to the clouds, we might commend;
But he that 'fore the gods, himÅ¿elf preferrs,
Is more prophane, then groÅ¿Å¿e Idolaters;
And though no gods, if he eÅ¿teem them Å¿ome,
And contemn them, woful is his doome.
He after this, Å¿aw in a ViÅ¿ion,
His brother Smerdis Å¿it upon his throne;
He Å¿trait to rid himÅ¿elf of cauÅ¿leÅ¿Å¿e fears,
Complots the Princes death, in his green years,
Who for no wrong, poore innocent muÅ¿t dye,
PraraÅ¿pes now muÅ¿t act this tragedy;
Who into PerÅ¿ia with CommiÅ¿Å¿ion Å¿ent,
AccompliÅ¿hed this wicked Kings intent;
His Å¿iÅ¿ter, whom inceÅ¿tuouÅ¿ly he wed,
Hearing her harmleÅ¿Å¿e brother thus was dead,
His woful fate with tears did Å¿o bemoane,
That by her Husbands charge, Å¿he caught her owne;
She with her fruit was both at once undone,
Who would have born a Nephew, and a Son.
O helliÅ¿h Husband, Brother, Vnckle, Sire,
Thy cruelty will Ages Å¿till admire.
This Å¿trange Å¿everity, one time he us'd,
Upon a Judge, for breach of Law accus'd;
Flayd him alive, hung up his Å¿tuffed skin
Over his Seat, then plac'd his Son therein;
To whom he gave this in rememberance,
Like fault muÅ¿t look, for the like recompence.
PraraÅ¿pes, to CambyÅ¿es favourite,
Having one Å¿on, in whom he did delight,
His cruell MaÅ¿ter, for all Å¿ervice done,
Shot through the heart of his beloved Å¿on:
And only for his fathers faithfullneÅ¿Å¿e,
Who Å¿aid but what, the King bad him expreÅ¿Å¿e.
'T would be no pleaÅ¿ant, but a tedious thing,
To tell the facts, of this moÅ¿t bloody King.
Fear'd of all, but lov'd of few, or none,
All thought his Å¿hort r â¢ ign long, till it was done
At laÅ¿t, two of his Officers he heart,
Had Å¿et a Smerdis up, of the Å¿ame years;
And like in feature, to the Smerdis dead,
Ruling as they thought good, under his head.
Toucht with this newes, to PerÅ¿ia he makes,
But in the way, his Å¿word juÅ¿t vÃ©ngeance takes.
UnÅ¿heathes, as he his horÅ¿e mounted on high,
And with a Martall thruÅ¿t, wounds him ith' thigh,
Which ends before begun, the PerÅ¿ian Wa â¢ re,
Yeelding to death, that dreadfull Conquerer.
Griefe for his brothers death, he did expreÅ¿Å¿e,
And more, becauÅ¿e he dyed iÅ¿Å¿uleÅ¿Å¿e.
The Male line, of great Cyrus now did end.
The Female many ages did extend,
A Babylon in Egypt did he make.
And built fair Meroe, for his Å¿iÅ¿ters Å¿ake.
Eight years he reign'd, a Å¿hort, yet too long time,
Cut off in's wickedneÅ¿Å¿e, in's Å¿trength, and prime.

lg.head: The inter Regnum between CambyÅ¿es, and Darius HyÅ¿laÅ¿pes.
lg.l: ChildleÅ¿Å¿e CambyÅ¿es, on the Å¿udden dead,
The Princes meet to chuÅ¿e one in his Å¿tead,

This King, with conÅ¿pirators Å¿o Å¿tout,
Who little pleaÅ¿ure had, in his Å¿hort reigne,

But yet, 'fore this was done, much blood was Å¿hed,

Some write that Å¿orely hurt, they 'Å¿cap'd away;
But Å¿o or no, Å¿ure tis, they won the day.
All things in peace, and Rebells throughly que â¢ 'd,
A ConÅ¿ultation by the States was held.
What forme of Government now to erect,
The old, or new, which beÅ¿t, in what reÅ¿pect,
The greater part, declin'd a Monarchy.
So late cruÅ¿ht by their Princes Tyranny;
And thought the people, would more happy be,
If governed by an AriÅ¿tocracy.
But others thought (none of the dulleÅ¿t braine,)
But b â¢ tter one, then many Tyrants reigne.
What arguments they us'd, I know not well,
Too politicke (tis like) for me to tell,
But in concluÅ¿ion they all agree,
That of the Å¿even a Monarch choÅ¿en be;
All envie to avoyd, this was thought on,
Upon a Green to meet, by riÅ¿ing Sun;
And he whoÅ¿e HorÅ¿e before the reÅ¿t Å¿hould neigh,
Of all the Peers Å¿hould have precedency.
They all attend on the appointed houre,
Praying to Fortune, for a Kingly power;
Then mounting on their Å¿norting courÅ¿ers proud,
Darius luÅ¿ty Å¿tallion neighed full loud;
The Nobles all alight, their King to greet,
And after PerÅ¿ian manner, kiÅ¿Å¿e his feet.
His happy wiÅ¿hes now doth no man Å¿pare,

A thouÅ¿and times, God Å¿ave the King, they cry,

Thanks for all this to's crafty Stable-groome.

lg.head: Darius HyÅ¿lapÅ¿es.
lg.l: DArius by election made a King,
His title to make Å¿trong omits no thing;
He two of Cyrus Daughters now doth wed,
Two of his Neeces takes to nuptiall bed;
By which he cuts their hopes (for future times)
That by Å¿uch Å¿teps to Kingdoms often climbs.
And now a King, by marriage, choyce, and bloud,
Three Å¿trings to's bow, the leaÅ¿t of which is good;
Yet more the peoples hearts firmly to binde,
Made wholÅ¿ome gentle Laws, which pleas'd each mind.
His affability, and milde aÅ¿pect,
Did win him loyalty, and all reÅ¿pect;
Yet notwithÅ¿tanding he did all Å¿o well,
The Babylonians 'gainÅ¿t their Prince rebell;

But Å¿trength againÅ¿t thoÅ¿e walls was of no uÅ¿e;

His manly face diÅ¿-figures, Å¿pares no bloud,

That for their Å¿akes, his cruelty he felt;
DeÅ¿iring of the Prince to raiÅ¿e the Å¿iege,
This violence was done him by his Leige;
This told, for enterance he Å¿tood not long,
For they beleev'd his noÅ¿e, more then his tongue;
With all the Cities Å¿trength they him betruÅ¿t,
If he command, obey the greateÅ¿t muÅ¿t:
When opportunity he Å¿aw was fit,
Delivers up the town, and all in it.
To looÅ¿e a noÅ¿e, to win a Town's no Å¿hame,
But who dare venture Å¿uch a Å¿take for th' game;
Then thy diÅ¿grace, thine honour's manifold,
Who doth deÅ¿erve a Statue made of gold;
Nor can Darius in his Monarchy,
ScarÅ¿e finde enough to thank thy loyalty;
But yet thou haÅ¿t Å¿ufficient recompence,
In that thy fame Å¿hall Å¿ound whilÅ¿t men have Å¿ence;
Yet o're thy glory we muÅ¿t caÅ¿t this vaile,
Thy falÅ¿hood, not thy valour did prevaile;
Thy wit was more then was thine honeÅ¿ty,
Thou lov'dÅ¿t thy MaÅ¿ter more then verity.
Darius in the Å¿econd of his reign,
An Edict for the Jews publiÅ¿h'd again,
The temple to re-build, for that did reÅ¿t
Since Cyrus time, CambyÅ¿es did moleÅ¿t;

Set up a Temple (though, a leÅ¿Å¿e) again.
Darius on the Sythians made a war,
Entring that large and barren country far;

Over fair IÅ¿ter, at a mighty charge;
But in that DeÅ¿art, 'mongÅ¿t his barbarous foes,

Which two then to aÅ¿Å¿aile, his Camp was bold:
By theÅ¿e alone his HoaÅ¿t was pinch'd Å¿o Å¿ore,

The Salvages did laugh at his diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿e,
Their minds by Hieroglyphicks they expreÅ¿Å¿e;
A Frog, a MouÅ¿e, a Bird, an Arrow Å¿ent,
The King will needs interpret their intent;
PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of water, earth, and aire,
But wiÅ¿e Gobrias reads not half Å¿o farre:
Quoth he, like Frogs, in water we muÅ¿t dive,
Or like to Mice, under the earth muÅ¿t live;

Or Sythian arrows in our fides muÅ¿t Å¿tick.
The King, Å¿eeing his men, and victuall Å¿pent,
His fruitleÅ¿Å¿e war, began late to repent;
Return'd with little honour, and leÅ¿Å¿e gaine,
His enemies Å¿carce Å¿een, then much leÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿laine;

But troubles in leÅ¿Å¿e AÅ¿ia him Å¿tay'd;

Athens perceiving now their deÅ¿perate Å¿tate,

At Marathon this bloudy field was fought,

The PerÅ¿ians to their Gallies poÅ¿t with Å¿peed,
Where an Athenian Å¿hew'd a valiant deed,

He Å¿tayes a landing Gally with his hand;

Go PerÅ¿ians, carry home that angry peece,

And for revenge his heart Å¿till reÅ¿tleÅ¿Å¿e burnes;
His Queen AttoÅ¿Å¿a, cauÅ¿ed all this Å¿tir,

('Tis thought) through grief of his Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e Å¿trife.
Thirty Å¿ix years this royall Prince did reign,

lg.head: Xerxes.
lg.l: XErxes, Darius, and AttoÅ¿Å¿a's Son,
Grand-childe to Cyrus, now Å¿its on the throne;
The Father not Å¿o full of lenity,
As is the Son, of pride, and cruelty;

Th' Aegyptians to reduce, and Greece to marre;
The firÅ¿t begun, and finiÅ¿h'd in Å¿uch haÅ¿t,
None write by whom, nor how, 'twas over-paÅ¿t;

His Souldiers, credit, wealth, at home had Å¿tay'd,

The firÅ¿t deports, and layes before his eyes,
His Fathers ill Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e in's enterpriÅ¿e,
AgainÅ¿t the Sythians, and Grecians too,
What infamy to's honour did accrue.
Flattering Mardonius on th' other Å¿ide,
With certainty of Europe feeds his pride;
Vaine Xerxes thinks his counÅ¿ell hath moÅ¿t wit,

And by this choyce, unwarily poÅ¿ts on,
To preÅ¿ent loÅ¿Å¿e, future Å¿ubverÅ¿ion;
Although he haÅ¿ted, yet foure yeares was Å¿pent,

That the large PerÅ¿ian government Å¿urrounded;
His Foot was Å¿eventeen hundred thouÅ¿and Å¿trong,
Eight hundred thouÅ¿and HorÅ¿e to them belong;
His Camels, beaÅ¿ts, for carriage numberleÅ¿Å¿e,
For truth's aÅ¿ham'd how many to expreÅ¿Å¿e;
The charge of all he Å¿everally commended,
To Princes of the PerÅ¿ian bloud deÅ¿cended,
But the command of theÅ¿e Commanders all,
To Mardonius, Captain Generall;
He was the Son of the fore-nam'd Gobrias,
Who married the Å¿iÅ¿ter of Darius:
TheÅ¿e his Land Forces were, then next, a Fleet
Of two and twenty thouÅ¿and Gallies meet,
Mann'd by PheniÅ¿ians, and Pamphilians,
Cipriots, Dorians, and Cilicians,
Lycians, Carians, and Ionians,
Eolians, and the HeliÅ¿pontines;
BeÅ¿ides, the VeÅ¿Å¿els for his tranÅ¿portation,
Three thouÅ¿and (or more) by beÅ¿t relation,
ArtemeÅ¿ia, Halicarna's Queene,
In perÅ¿on there, now for his help was Å¿een;
WhoÅ¿e Gallies all the reÅ¿t in neatneÅ¿Å¿e paÅ¿Å¿e,
Save the Zidonians, where Xerxes was.
Hers Å¿he kept Å¿til, Å¿eperate from the reÅ¿t,
For to command alone, Å¿he thought was beÅ¿t.
O noble Queen, thy valour I commend,
But pitty 'twas, thine ayde that here did'Å¿t lend,
At Sardis, in Lidia, theÅ¿e all doe meet,
Whither rich Pithyus comes, Xerxes to greet;
FeaÅ¿ts all this multitude, of his own charge,
Then gives the King, a King-like gift, moÅ¿t large;
Three thouÅ¿and Tallents of the pureÅ¿t gold;
Which mighty Å¿ â¢ m, all wondred to behold.
He humbly to the King then makes requeÅ¿t,
One of his five Sons there, might be relead;
To be to's age a comfort, and a Å¿tay,
The other four he freely gave away:
The King cals for the Youth, who being brought,
Cuts him in twain, for whom his Sire beÅ¿ought.
O moÅ¿t inhumain incivility!
Nay, more then monÅ¿trous barb'rous cruelty!
For his great love, is this thy recompence?
Is this to doe like Xerxes, or a Prince?
Thou Å¿hame of Kings, of men the deteÅ¿tation,
I Rhetorick want, to poure out execration:
FirÅ¿t thing, Xerxes did worthy recount,
A Sea paÅ¿Å¿age cuts, behind Orthos Mount.
Next, o're the HelliÅ¿pont a bridge he made,
Of Boats, together coupled, and there laid;
But winds, and waves, theÅ¿e couples Å¿oon diÅ¿Å¿ever'd,

Seven dayes and nights, his HoaÅ¿t without leaÅ¿t Å¿tay,
Was marching o're this interrupting Bay;

He glories in his Squadrens, and his HorÅ¿es;

One King, Å¿o many Subjects Å¿hould poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e;

How of this enterpriÅ¿e his thoughts now Å¿tands;

The Spartan meets him, brave Leonade,
This 'twixt the Mountains lyes (half Acre wide)
That pleaÅ¿ant TheÅ¿Å¿aly, from Greece divide;

They thus behemm'd with multitude of foes,

O noble Greeks, how now, degenerate?
Where is the valour, of your antient State?
When as one thouÅ¿and, could Å¿ome Millions daunt;

This Å¿hamefull Victory coÅ¿t Xerxes deare,
AmongÅ¿t the reÅ¿t, two brothers he loÅ¿t there;

That their Å¿plit Å¿ides, witneÅ¿Å¿'d his overthrow;

They no way able to withÅ¿tand his force,

Two mighty Rocks, brake from ParnaÅ¿Å¿us Hil,

(Chief inÅ¿tigater of this hopeleÅ¿Å¿e War;)
He inÅ¿tantly to Athens Å¿ends for peace,

The Spartans, fearing Athens would agree,
As had Macedon, Thebes, and TheÅ¿Å¿alie,
And leave them out, the Å¿hock for to Å¿uÅ¿taine,
By their AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador they thus complain;

But the Athenians, this peace deteÅ¿t,
And thus reply'd unto Mardon's requeÅ¿t;
That whilÅ¿t the Sun did run his endleÅ¿Å¿e courÅ¿e,
AgainÅ¿t the PerÅ¿ians they would uÅ¿e their force.
Nor could the brave AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador be Å¿ent,

Though of this Nation borne a great Commander,
No leÅ¿Å¿e then Grand-Å¿ire to great Alexander.
Mardonius proud, hearing this anÅ¿wer Å¿tout,
To adde unto his numbers, layes about,
And of thoÅ¿e Greeks, which by his skil he'd won,
He fifty thouÅ¿and joynes unto his own;
The other Greeks, which were confederate,
One hundred thouÅ¿and, and ten thouÅ¿and make.
The Beotian Fields, of war, the Å¿eats,
Where both Å¿ides exercis'd their manly feats;
But all their controverÅ¿ies to decide,
For one maine Battell Å¿hortly, both provide;
The Athenians could but forty thouÅ¿and arme,
For other Weapons, they had none would harme;
But that which helpt defects, and made them bold,
Was Victory, by Oracle fore-told:
Ten dayes theÅ¿e Armies did each other face,
Mardonius finding victuals waÅ¿t apace,
No longer dar'd, but fiercely on-Å¿et gave,
The other not a hand, nor Å¿word will wave,
Till in the entrails of their Sacrifice,
The Å¿ignall of their victory doth riÅ¿e;
Which found, like Greeks they fight, the PerÅ¿ians fly,
And troubleÅ¿ome Mardonius now muÅ¿t dye:
All's loÅ¿t, and of three hundred thouÅ¿and men,
Three thouÅ¿and Å¿capes, for to run home agen;
For pitty, let thoÅ¿e few to Xerxes go,
To c â¢ rtifie this finall over-throw.
Same day, the Å¿mall remainder of his Fleet,
The Grecians at Mytale in AÅ¿ia meet,
And there Å¿o utterly they wrack'd the Å¿ame,
Scarce one was left, to carry home the fame;
Thus did the Greeks deÅ¿troy, conÅ¿ume, diÅ¿perce,
That Army, which did fright the UniverÅ¿e;
Scorn'd Xerxes, hated for his cruelty.
Yet ceaÅ¿es not to act his villany:
His brothers wife, Å¿ollicites to his will;
The chaÅ¿te, and beautious Dame, refuÅ¿es Å¿till.
Some years by him in this vain Å¿uit was Å¿pent,
Yet words, nor guifts, could win him leaÅ¿t content:
Nor matching of her daughter; to his Å¿on:
But Å¿he was Å¿til, as when it firÅ¿t begun.
When jealous Queen AmeÅ¿tris, of this knew,
She Harpy-like, upon the Lady flew:
Cut off her lilly breaÅ¿ts, her noÅ¿e, and ears;
And leaves her thus, beÅ¿mear'd with blood, and tears
Straight comes her Lord, and finds his wife thus lie,
The Å¿orrow of his heart, did cloÅ¿e his eye:
He dying to behold, that wounding Å¿ight;
Where he had Å¿ometime gaz'd with great delight.
To Å¿ee that face, where RoÅ¿e and Lilly Å¿tood,
O're-flown with torrent of her ruby blood.
To Å¿ee thoÅ¿e breaÅ¿ts, where chaÅ¿tity did dwel,
Thus cut, and mangled by a hag of hell.
With loaden heart unto the King he goes,
Tels as he could, his unexpreÅ¿Å¿ed woes,
But for his deep complaints; and Å¿howres of tears,
His brothers recompence was naught but jears:
The grieved Prince finding nor right, nor l â¢ ve,
To Bactria his houÅ¿hold did remove.
His wicked brother, after Å¿ent a crew,
Which him, and his, moÅ¿t barbarouÅ¿ly there Å¿lew,
Unto Å¿uch height did grow his cruelty,
Of life, no man had leaÅ¿t Å¿ecurity.
At laÅ¿t his Uncle, did his death conÅ¿pire,
And for that end, his Eunuch he d â¢ d hire.
Which wretch, him privately Å¿mother'd in's bed,
But yet by Å¿earch, he was found murthered,
The Artacanus hirer of this deed,
That from Å¿uÅ¿pition he might be freed,
Accus'd Darius, Xerxes eldeÅ¿t Å¿on,
To be the Authour of the deed was done,
And by his craft, ordered the matter Å¿o,

But in Å¿hort time, this wickedneÅ¿Å¿e was knowne,

But all his family was likewiÅ¿e Å¿lain,
Such JuÅ¿tice then, in PerÅ¿ia did remain,

lg.head: Artaxerxes Longimanus.
lg.l: AMongÅ¿t the Monarchs next, this Prince had place

Greeks and Egyptians both, he overthrows,

His hangings, white, and green, and purple dye;

What HeÅ¿ter was, and did, her Å¿tory reed,

Of Hamans fall, and Mordica's great riÅ¿e;
The might o'th' Prince, the tribute on the IÅ¿les.
Unto this King ThymiÅ¿tocles did flye.
When under OÅ¿traciÅ¿me he did lye.
For Å¿uch ingratitude, did Athens Å¿how
This valiant Knight, whom they Å¿o much did owe;

The King not little joyfull of this chance,

And for that end, great preparation made,
Fair Attica, a third time to invade.
His Grand-Å¿ires old diÅ¿grace, did vex him Å¿ore,
His father Xerxes loÅ¿Å¿e, and Å¿hame, much more,

The noble Greek, now fit for generall.
Who for his wrong, he could not chuÅ¿e but deem,
His Country, nor his Kindred would eÅ¿teem,
ProviÅ¿ions, and Å¿eaÅ¿on now being fit,
T'ThymiÅ¿tecles he doth his war commit,

And to his Country-men could bear no hate.
Nor yet diÅ¿loyall to his Prince would prove,
To whom oblig'd, by favour, and by love;
Either to wrong, did wound his heart Å¿o Å¿ore,
To wrong himÅ¿elfe by death, he choÅ¿e before:
In this Å¿ad conflict, marching on his ways,
Strong poyÅ¿on took, and put an end to's dayes.
The King this noble Captaine having loÅ¿t,
Again diÅ¿perÅ¿ed, his new levyed hoaÅ¿t.

lg.head: Daryus Nothus.
lg.l: THree Å¿ons great Artaxerxes left behind;
The eldeÅ¿t to Å¿ucceed, that was his mind.

Then the Å¿urviver is by Nothus Å¿laine;

TheÅ¿e two lewd Å¿ons, are by hyÅ¿torians thought,

If they were hers, the greater was her moon;
That for Å¿uch graceleÅ¿Å¿e wretches Å¿he did groan,
DiÅ¿quiet Egypt, 'gainÅ¿t this King rebells,
Drives out his gariÅ¿on that therein dwels.
Joynes with the Greeks, and Å¿o maintains their right,
For Å¿ixty years maugre the PerÅ¿ians might.
A Å¿econd trouble, after this Å¿ucceeds.
Which from remiÅ¿Å¿eneÅ¿Å¿e, in AÅ¿ia proceeds
Amerges, whom their Vice-roy he ordain'd
Revolts, having treaÅ¿ure, and people gain'd:
Invades the Country, and much trouble wrought,
Before to quietneÅ¿Å¿e things could be brought,
The King was glad, with Sparta to make peace,
So that he might, theÅ¿e tumults Å¿oon appeaÅ¿e.
But they in AÅ¿ia, muÅ¿t firÅ¿t reÅ¿tore
All Townes, held by his AnceÅ¿tors before.
The King much profit reapeth, by theÅ¿e leagues,
Re-gaines his own, and then the Rebell breaks:
WhoÅ¿e forces by their helpe were overthrown,
And Å¿o each man again poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿t his owne.
The King, his Å¿iÅ¿ter, like CambyÅ¿es, wed;
More by his pride, then luÅ¿t, thereunto led.
(For PerÅ¿ian Kings, did deem themÅ¿elves Å¿o good,
No match was high enough, but their own blood,)
Two Å¿ons Å¿he bore, the youngeÅ¿t Cyrus nam'd,
A hopefull Prince, whoÅ¿e worth is ever fam'd.
His father would no notice of that take;
Prefers his brother, for his birth-rights Å¿ake.
But Cyrus Å¿cornes, his brothers feeble wit;
And takes more on him, then was judged fit.
The King provok'd, Å¿ends for him to the Court,
Meaning to chaÅ¿tiÅ¿e him, in Å¿harpeÅ¿t Å¿ort,

His large Dominions left, to's eldeÅ¿t Å¿on.

lg.head: Artaxerxes Mnemon.
lg.l: MNemon now fits upon his fathers Throne,
Yet doubts, all he injoyes, is not his own.
Still on his brother, caÅ¿ts a jealous eye,
Judging all's actions, tends to's injury.
Cyrus o'th' other Å¿ide, weighs in his mind,
What helps, in's enterprize he's like to find,
His intereÅ¿t, in the Kingdome, now next heir,
More deare to's mother, then his brother far.
His brothers litle love, like to be gone,
Held by his mothers interceÅ¿Å¿ion.
TheÅ¿e and like motives, hurry him amain,
To win by force, what right could not obtain.
And thought 'it beÅ¿t, now in his mothers time,
By leÅ¿Å¿er Å¿teps, towards the top to climbe;
If in his enterprize he Å¿hould fall Å¿hort,
She to the King, would make a fair report:
He hop'd, if fraud, nor force the Crown could gaine;
Her prevailence, a pardon might obtain.
From the Lieutenant firÅ¿t, he takes away,
Some Townes commodious in leÅ¿Å¿e AÅ¿ia,
Pretending Å¿till, the profit of the King,
WhoÅ¿e rents and cuÅ¿tomes, duly he Å¿ent in.
The King finding, revenues now amended;
For what was done, Å¿eemed no whit offended.
Then next, the Lacedemons he takes to pay;
(One Greeke could make ten PerÅ¿ians run away)
Great care was his pretence, thoÅ¿e Souldiers Å¿tout,
The Rovers in PiÅ¿idia, Å¿hould drive out.
But leaÅ¿t Å¿ome worÅ¿er newes Å¿hould fly to Court,
He meant himÅ¿elfe to carry the report.
And for that end, five hundred HorÅ¿e he choÅ¿e,
With poÅ¿ting Å¿peed towards the King he goes;
But fame more quick, arrives ere he came there,
And fills the Court with tumult, and with fear.
The young Queen, and old, at bitter jars:
The one accus'd the other, for theÅ¿e wars:
The wife, againÅ¿t the mother, Å¿till doth cry
To be the Author of conÅ¿piracy.
The King diÅ¿may'd, a mighty HoaÅ¿t doth raiÅ¿e;
Which Cyrus heares, and Å¿o fore-Å¿lowes his pace:
But as he goes, his Forces Å¿till augments,
Seven hundred Greeks now further his intents:
And others to be warm'd by this new Å¿un,
In numbers from his brother daily run.
The fearfull King, at laÅ¿t, muÅ¿ters his Forces;
And counts nine hundred thouÅ¿and foot and horÅ¿es:
And yet with theÅ¿e, had neither heart, nor grace;
To lo â¢ k his manly brother in the face.
Three hundred thouÅ¿and, yet to Syria Å¿ent;
To keep thoÅ¿e Å¿treights, to hinder his intent.
Their Captain hearing, but of Cyrus name.
Ran back, and quire abandoned the Å¿ame,
Abrccomes, was this baÅ¿e cowards name,
Not worthy to be known, but for his Å¿hame:
This place was made, by nature, and by art;
Few might have kept it, had they but a heart.
Cyrus diÅ¿pair'd, a paÅ¿Å¿age there to gain;
So hir'd a fleet, to waft him ore the Maine,
The mazed King, was now about to fly;
To th'utmoÅ¿t parts of Bactr'a, and there lye.
Had not a Captain; Å¿ore againÅ¿t his will;
By reaÅ¿on, and by force, detain'd him Å¿till.
Up then with Å¿peed, a mighty trench he throwes,
For his Å¿ecurity, againÅ¿t his foes.
Six yards the depth, and forty miles the length,
Some fifty, or elÅ¿e Å¿ixty foote in breadth.
Yet for his brothers comming, durÅ¿t not Å¿tay,
He Å¿ureÅ¿t was, when furtheÅ¿t out o'th' way.
Cyrus finding his campe, and no man there;
Rejoyced not a little at his feare.
On this, he and his Souldiers cueleÅ¿Å¿e grow,
And here, and there, in carts their Armes they throw,
When Å¿uddenly their Scouts come in and cry,
Arme, arme, the King is now approaching nigh;
In this confuÅ¿ion, each man as he might,
Gets on his armes, arayes himÅ¿elfe for fight;
And ranged Å¿tood, by great Euphrates Å¿ide,
The brunt of that huge multitude to bide.
Of whoÅ¿e great numbers, their intelligence,
Was gather'd by the duÅ¿t that roÅ¿e from thence:
Which like a mighty cloud darkned the skye;
And black and blacker grew, as they drew nigh
But when their order, and Å¿ilence they Å¿aw;
That, more then multitudes, their hearts did awe:
For tumult and confuÅ¿ion they expected,
And all good diÅ¿cipline to be neglected.
But long under their fears, they did not Å¿tay,
For at firÅ¿t charge the PerÅ¿ians ran away.
Which did Å¿uch courage to the Grecians bring,
They Å¿traight adored Cyrus for their King,
So had he been, and got the victory,
Had not his too much valour put him by.
He with Å¿ix hundred, on a Å¿quadron Å¿et,
Of Å¿ix thouÅ¿and, wherein the King was yet;
And brought his Souldiers on Å¿o gallantly,
They were about to leave their King and fly,
Whom Cyrus Å¿pi'd, cries cut, I Å¿ee the man,

But in his Å¿peed a Dart hit him i'th' eye,
Down Cyrus fals, and yeelds to deÅ¿tiny;
His HoÅ¿t in chaÅ¿e, knowes not of his diÅ¿aÅ¿ter,
But treads down all, for to advance their MaÅ¿ter;
At laÅ¿t his head they Å¿py upon a Launce,
Who knowes the Å¿udden change made by this chance;
SenceleÅ¿Å¿e and mute they Å¿tand, yet breath out groans,
Nor Gorgons like to this, transform'd to Å¿tones.
After this trance, revenge, new Å¿pirits blew,
And now more eagerly their foes purÅ¿ue,
And heaps on heaps, Å¿uch multitudes they laid,
Their armes grew weake, through Å¿laughters that they made.
The King unto a country Village flyes,
And for a while unkingly there he lyes;
At laÅ¿t, diÅ¿playes his EnÅ¿igne on a Hil,
Hoping with that to make the Greeks Å¿tand Å¿til,
But was deceiv'd; to it they make amain,
The King upon the Å¿pur, runs back again;
But they too faint, Å¿till to purÅ¿ue their game,
Being Victors oft, now to their Camp they came;
Nor lackt they any of their number Å¿mall,
Nor wound receiv'd, but one among them all:
The King with his diÅ¿pers'd alÅ¿o incampt.
With infamy upon each fore-head Å¿tampt;
After a while his thoughts he re-collects,
Of this dayes cowardize, he feares the effects;
If Greeks unto their Country-men declare,
What daÅ¿tards in the field the perÅ¿ians are;
They Å¿oone may come, and place one in his Throne,
And rob him both of Scepter, and of Crown;
That their return be Å¿topt, he judg'd was beÅ¿t,
That Å¿o Europians might no more moleÅ¿t;
Forth-with he Å¿ends to's Tent, they Å¿traight addreÅ¿Å¿e,
And there all wait his mercy, weaponleÅ¿Å¿e;
The Greeks with Å¿corn reject his proud commands;
Asking no favour, where they fear'd no bands.
The troubled King, his Herauld Å¿ends again,
And Å¿ues for peace, that they his friends remain;
The Å¿miling Greeks reply, they firÅ¿t muÅ¿t bait,
They were too hungry to capitulate;
The King great Å¿tore of all proviÅ¿ion Å¿ends,
And courteÅ¿ie to th' utmoÅ¿t he pretends;
Such terrour on the PerÅ¿ians then did fall,
They quak'd, to heare them, to each other call.
The King's perplext, there dares not let them Å¿tay,
And feares as much to let them march away;
But Kings ne're want Å¿uch as can Å¿erve their will,
Fit inÅ¿truments t' accompliÅ¿h what is ill;
As TyÅ¿Å¿aphern, knowing his MaÅ¿ters minde,

The Greeks, having their valiant Captaines Å¿laine,
ChoÅ¿e Xenophon, to lead them home again;
But TyÅ¿Å¿aphern did what he could deviÅ¿e,
To Å¿top the way in this their enterpriÅ¿e;
But when through difficulties Å¿till they brake,
He Å¿ought all Å¿uÅ¿tinance from them to take,
Before them burnt the country as they went,
So to deprive them of all nouriÅ¿hment;
But on they march, through hunger, and through cold,
O're mountains, rocks, and hils, as Lions bold;
Nor rivers courÅ¿e, nor PerÅ¿ians force could Å¿tay,
But on to Trabezond they kept their way;
There was of Greeks, Å¿etled a Colony,
TheÅ¿e after all, receiv'd them joyfully:
There for Å¿ome time they were, but whilÅ¿t they Å¿taid,
Into Bithynia often in rodes made;
The King afraid what further they might doe,
Unto the Spartan Admirall did Å¿ue,
Straight to tranÅ¿port them to the other Å¿ide,
For theÅ¿e incurÅ¿ions he durÅ¿t not abide;

The Greeks now (as the PerÅ¿ian King Å¿uÅ¿pects)
The AÅ¿iatiques, cowardize detects;
The many victories themÅ¿elves did gain,
The many thouÅ¿and PerÅ¿ians they had Å¿lain;
And now their Nation with facility,
Might win the univerÅ¿all Monarchy;
They then Dercilladas, Å¿end with an HoaÅ¿t,
Who with his Spartans on the AÅ¿ian coaÅ¿t;
Town after town, with Å¿mall reÅ¿iÅ¿tance take,
Which rumor makes great Artaxerxes quake;
The Greeks by this Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e, incourag'd Å¿o,
AgeÅ¿ilaus himÅ¿elf doth over-goe,
By th' Kings Lieutenant is encountered,
But TyÅ¿Å¿aphernes with his Army fled;
Which over-throw incens'd the King Å¿o Å¿ore,
That TyÅ¿Å¿apherne muÅ¿t be Vice-roy no more;
TythrauÅ¿tes now is placed in his Å¿tead,
And hath command, to take the others head,
Of that falÅ¿e perjur'd wretch, this was the laÅ¿t,
Who of his cruelty made many taÅ¿t,
TythrauÅ¿tes truÅ¿ts more to his wit then Arms,

The Spartans height, which now apace doth riÅ¿e;

AgeÅ¿tilaus is called home with Å¿peed,

They now loÅ¿t all, and were a peace to make,

DiÅ¿Å¿ention in Greece continued long,

'MongÅ¿t theÅ¿e Epimanondas wants no fame;

But let us leave theÅ¿e Greeks, to diÅ¿cord bent,

lg.head: Darius Ochus.
lg.l: GReat Artexerxes dead, Ochus Å¿ucceeds,
Of whom no Record's extant of his deeds;

Their Acts recorded not, as heretofore?

lg.head: ArÅ¿ames, or ArÅ¿es.
lg.l: WHy ArÅ¿ames his brother Å¿hould Å¿ucceed,

lg.head: Darius Codomanus.
lg.l: HOw this Darius did attain the Crown,
By favour, force, or fraud, is not Å¿et down:

By one of theÅ¿e, he muÅ¿t obtain the place.
Some writers Å¿ay, that he was ArÅ¿es Å¿on,
And that great Cyrus line, yet was not run,

That Å¿on, and father, both were murthered
By one Bagoas, an Eunuch (as is Å¿ed.)
Thus learned Pemble, whom we may not Å¿light,
But as before doth (well read) Raleigh write,
Antd he that Å¿tory reads, Å¿hall often find;
That Å¿everall men, will have their Å¿everall mind;
Yet in theÅ¿e differences, we may behold;
With our judicious learned Knight to hold.
And this 'mongÅ¿t all's no controverted thing,
That this Darius was laÅ¿t PerÅ¿ian King,
WhoÅ¿e warres and loÅ¿Å¿es we may better tell;

And laÅ¿t; a Å¿ad cataÅ¿trophe to end,
Him, to the grave, did â¢ raytor BeÅ¿Å¿us Å¿end.
The end of the PerÅ¿ian Monarchy.

div.head: The third Monarchy was the Grecian, beginning under Alexander the Great, in the 112 Olimpiad.

lg.l: GReat Alexander, was wiÅ¿e Phillips Å¿on,
He, to Amintas, Kings of Macedon;
The cruell, proud, Olimpias, was his mother,
Shee to the rich MoloÅ¿Å¿ians King, was daughter.
This Prince (his father by PauÅ¿anias Å¿lain)
The twenty firÅ¿t of 's age, began to reign.
Great were the guifts of nature, which be had;
His Education, much to theÅ¿e did adde.
By Art, and Nature both, he was made fit,
T'accompliÅ¿h that, which long before was writ.
The very day of his nativity,
To th' ground was burnt, Diana's Temple high,
An Omen, to their near approaching woe;
WhoÅ¿e glory to the Earth, this Prince did throw,
His rule to Greece, he Å¿corn'd Å¿hould be confin'd:
The univerÅ¿e, Å¿carce bounds his large vaÅ¿t minde;
This is the hee-goat, which from Grecia came,
Who ran in fury, on the PerÅ¿ian Ram,
That broke his hornes, that threw him on the ground,
To Å¿ave him from his might, no man was found.
Phillip, on this great conqueÅ¿t had an eye;
But death did terminate, thoÅ¿e thoughts Å¿o high.
The Greeks had choÅ¿e him Captain Generall,
Which honour to his Å¿on, now did befall.
(For as worlds Monarch, now we Å¿peak not on,
But as the King of little Macedon)
ReÅ¿tleÅ¿Å¿e both day and night, his heart now was,
His high reÅ¿olves which way to bring to paÅ¿Å¿e:
Yet for a while, in Grecce is forc'd to Å¿tay,
Which makes each moment Å¿eem, more then a day:
Thebes, and old Athens, both 'gainÅ¿t him rebell,

This

After Epiphanes, Å¿at on the Throne

The AÅ¿Å¿yrian Monarchy long time did Å¿tand,

l.hi: AFter Å¿ome dayes of reÅ¿t, my reÅ¿tleÅ¿Å¿e heart,

div.head: The Roman Monarchy, being the Fourth, and laÅ¿t, beginning, Anno Mundi, 3213.

lg.l: STout Romulus, Romes Founder, and firÅ¿t King,
Whom veÅ¿tall Rhea, into th' world did bring
His Father was not Mars, as Å¿ome devis'd,
But Aemulus, in Armour all diÅ¿guis'd.
Thus he deceiv'd his Neece, Å¿he might not know
The double injury, he then did doe:
Where Shepheards once had Coats, and Sheep their Folds,
Where Swaines, and ruÅ¿tick PeaÅ¿ants made their Holds.
A Citty faire did Romulus erect:
The MiÅ¿tris of the World, in each reÅ¿pect.
His Brother Remus there, by him was Å¿laine,
For leaping o're the Walls with Å¿ome diÅ¿daine;
The Stones at firÅ¿t was cimented with bloud,
And bloudy hath it proy'd, Å¿ince firÅ¿t it Å¿tood:
This City built, and Sacrifices done,
A forme of Government he next begun;

His City to repleniÅ¿h, men he wants,

Of Wives there was Å¿o great a Å¿carÅ¿ity,

So Romulus was forc'd this courÅ¿e to take.
Great Å¿hewes he makes at Tilt, and Turnament,
To Å¿ee theÅ¿e Å¿ports, the Sabins all are bent;
Their Daughters by the Romans then were caught,

But in the en â¢ , to finall peace they come,

The Romans now more potent 'gin to grow,

lg.head: Numa Pompilius.
lg.l: NVmt Pompilius, is next choÅ¿en King,

GoddeÅ¿Å¿e Aegeria this to him told,

lg.head: Tullus HoÅ¿tilius.
lg.l: TUllus HoÅ¿tilius, was third Roman King,

The Romans Conquereth, others yeeld the day,
Yet for their compact, after falÅ¿e they play:
The Romans Å¿ore incens'd, their Generall Å¿lay,
And from old Alba fetch the wealth away;
Of Latine Kings this was long Å¿ince the Seat,
But now demoliÅ¿hed, to make Rome great.
Thirty two years doth Tullus reigne, then dye,
Leaves Rome, in wealth and power, Å¿till growing high.

lg.head: Ancus Martius.
lg.l: NExt, Ancus Martius Å¿its upon the Throne,
Nephew unto Pomphilius dead, and gone;
Rome he inlarg'd, new built againe the wall,
Much Å¿tronger, and more beautifull withall;
A Å¿tately Bridge he over Tyber made,

Faire OÅ¿tia he built, this Town, it Å¿tood,

lg.head: Tarquinius PriÅ¿cus.
lg.l: TArquin, a Greek, at Corinth borne, and bred,
Who for Å¿edition from his Country fled;
Is entertain'd at Rome, and in Å¿hort time,
By wealth, and favour, doth to honour climbe;
He after Martius death the Kingdome had,
A hundred Senatours he more did adde;
Warres with the Latins he againe renewes,
And Nations twelve, of TuÅ¿cany Å¿ubdues:
To Å¿uch rude triumphs, as young Rome then had,
Much Å¿tate, and glory, did this PriÅ¿cus adde:
Thirty eight yeares (this Stranger borne) did reigne,
And after all, by Ancus Sons was Å¿laine.

lg.head: Servius Tullius.
lg.l: NExt, Servius Tullius Å¿its upon the Throne,
AÅ¿cends not up, by merits of his owne,
But by the favour, and the Å¿peciall grace

He ranks the people, into each degree,

lg.head: Tarquinius Superbus, the laÅ¿t Roman King.
lg.l: TArquin the proud, from manners called Å¿o,

She loathed Å¿o the fact, Å¿he loath'd h â¢ r life,
And Å¿hed her guiltleÅ¿Å¿e blood, with guilty knife.
Her Husband Å¿ore incens'd, to quit this wrong,

The Tarquins they from Rome with Å¿peed expell,
In baniÅ¿hment perpetuall, to dwell;

div.trailer: The end of the Roman Monarchy; being the fourth and laÅ¿t.

div.head: A Dialogue between Old England and New, concerning their preÅ¿ent troubles. Anno 1642.

lg.head: New England.
lg.l: ALas, deare Mother, faireÅ¿t Queen, and beÅ¿t,
With honour, wealth, and peace, happy and bleÅ¿t,
What ayles thee hang thy head, and croÅ¿Å¿e thine armes?
And Å¿it i'th duÅ¿t, to Å¿igh theÅ¿e Å¿ad alarms?
What deluge of new woes thus over-whelme
The glories of thy ever famous Realme?
What meanes this wailing tone, this mourning guiÅ¿e?
Ah, tell thy Daughter, Å¿he may Å¿impathize.

lg.head: Old England.
lg.l: Art ignorant indeed, of theÅ¿e my woes?
Or muÅ¿t my forc â¢ d tongue theÅ¿e grief â¢ s diÅ¿cloÅ¿e?
And muÅ¿t my Å¿elfe diÅ¿Å¿ect my tatter'd Å¿tate,
Which 'mazed ChriÅ¿tendom â¢ Å¿tands wondring at?
And thou a childe, a Limbe, and doÅ¿t not feele
My weakned fainting body now to reele?
This PhiÅ¿ick-purging-potion I have taken,
Will bring ConÅ¿umption, or an Ague quaking,
UnleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿ome Cordial thou fetch from high,
Which preÅ¿ent help may eaÅ¿e this malady.
If I deceaÅ¿e, doÅ¿t think thou Å¿halt Å¿urvive?
Or by my waÅ¿ting Å¿tate, doÅ¿t think to thrive?
Then weigh our caÅ¿e, if't be not juÅ¿tly Å¿ad,
Let me lament alone, while thou art glad.

lg.head: New England.
lg.l: And thus, alas, your Å¿tate you much deplore,
In generall terms, but will not Å¿ay wherefore:
What Medicine Å¿hall I Å¿eek to cure this woe,
If th' wound's Å¿o dangerous I may not know?
But you perhaps would have me gueÅ¿Å¿e it out,
What, hath Å¿ome HengiÅ¿t, like that Saxon Å¿tout,
By fraud, and force, uÅ¿urp'd thy flowring crown,
And by tempeÅ¿tuous Wars thy fields trod down?
Or hath Canutus, that brave valiant Dane,
The regall, peacefull Scepter from thee tane?
Or is't a Norman, whoÅ¿e victorious hand
With EngliÅ¿h blood bedews thy conquered Land?
Or is't inteÅ¿tine Wars that thus offend?
Doe Maud, and Stephen for the Crown contend?
Doe Barons riÅ¿e, and Å¿ide againÅ¿t their King?
And call in Forreign ayde, to help the thing?
MuÅ¿t Edward be depos'd, or is't the houre
That Å¿econd Richard muÅ¿t be clapt i'th' Tower?
Or is the fatall jarre againe begun,
That from the red, white pricking RoÅ¿es Å¿prung?
MuÅ¿t Richmonds ayd, the Nobles now implore,
To come, and break the tuÅ¿hes of the Boar?
If none of theÅ¿e, deare Mother, what's your woe?
Pray, doe not feare Spaines bragging Armado?
Doth your Allye, faire France, conÅ¿pire your wrack?
Or, doth the Scots play falÅ¿e behind your back?
Doth Holland quit you ill, for all your love?
Whence is this Å¿torme, from Earth, or Heaven above?
Is't Drought, is't Famine, or is't PeÅ¿tilence?
DoÅ¿t feele the Å¿mart, or feare the conÅ¿equence?
Your humble Childe intreats you, Å¿hew your grief,
Though Armes, nor PurÅ¿e Å¿he hath, for your releif:
Such is her poverty, yet Å¿hall be found
A Å¿upplyant for your help, as Å¿he is bound.

lg.head: Old England.
lg.l: I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿ome of thoÅ¿e Sores you name,
But forraigne Foe, nor fained friend I feare,
For they have work enough (thou knowÅ¿t) elÅ¿ewhere;
Nor is it Alcies Son, and Henries Daughter,
WhoÅ¿e proud contention cauÅ¿e this Å¿laughter;
Nor Nobles Å¿i â¢ ing, to make John no King
French Lewis unjuÅ¿tly to the Crown to bring;
No Edward, Richard, to l â¢ Å¿e rule, and life,
Nor no LancaÅ¿trians, to renew old Å¿trife;
No Crook-backt Tyrant, now uÅ¿urps the Seat,
WhoÅ¿e tearing tusks did wound, and kill, and threat:
No Duke of York, nor Earle of March, to Å¿oyle
Their hands in Kindreds blood, whom they did foyle:
No need of Teder, RoÅ¿es to unite,
None knowes which is the Red, or which the White:
Spaines braving Fleet a Å¿econd time is Å¿unke,
France knowes, how of my Å¿ury Å¿he hath drunk;
By Edward third, and Henry fifth of fame,
Her Lillies in mine Armes avouch the Å¿ame.
My SiÅ¿ter Scotland hurts me now no more,
Though Å¿he hath bin injurious heretofore.
What Holland is, I am in Å¿ome Å¿uÅ¿pence,
But truÅ¿t not much unto his Excellence;
For wants, Å¿ure Å¿ome I feele, but more I feare,
And for the PeÅ¿tilence, who knowes how neare;
Famine, and Plague, two Å¿iÅ¿ters of the Sword,
DeÅ¿truction to a Land doth Å¿oone afford;
They're for my puniÅ¿hments ordain'd on high,
UnleÅ¿Å¿e thy teares prevent it Å¿peedily.
But yet, I anÅ¿wer not what you demand,
To Å¿hew the grievance of my troubled Land;
Before I tell the effect, ile Å¿hew the cauÅ¿e,
Which are my Sins, the breach of Å¿acred Lawes;
Idolatry, Å¿upplanter of a Nation,
With fooliÅ¿h Å¿uperÅ¿titious adoration;
And lik'd, and countenanc'd by men of might,
The GoÅ¿pel is trod down, and hath no right;
Church Offices are Å¿old, and bought, for gaine,
That Pope, had hope, to finde Rome here againe;
For Oathes, and BlaÅ¿phemies did ever eare
From Beelzebub himÅ¿elf, Å¿uch language heare?
What Å¿corning of the Saints of the moÅ¿t high,
What injuries did daily on them lye;
What falÅ¿e reports, what nick-names did they take,
Not for their owne, but for their MaÅ¿ters Å¿ake;
And thou, poore Å¿oule, waÅ¿t jeer'd among the reÅ¿t,
Thy flying for the Truth I made a jeaÅ¿t;
For Sabbath-breaking, and for DrunkenneÅ¿Å¿e,
Did ever Land prophanneÅ¿Å¿e more expreÅ¿Å¿e?
From crying bloods, yet cleanÅ¿ed am not I,
Martyrs, and others, dying cauÅ¿eleÅ¿ly:
How many Princely heads on blocks laid down,
For nought, but title to a fading Crown?
'MongÅ¿t all the cruelties which I have done,
Oh, Edwards Babes, and Clare â¢ ce hapleÅ¿Å¿e Son,
O Jane, why didÅ¿t thou dye in flowring prime,
BecauÅ¿e of Royall Stem, that was thy crime;
For Bribery, Adultery, for Thefts, and Lyes,
Where is the Nation, I cann't paralize;
With UÅ¿ury, Extortion, and OppreÅ¿Å¿ion,
TheÅ¿e be the Hydra's of my Å¿tout tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ion;
TheÅ¿e be the bitter fountains, heads, and roots,
Whence flow'd the Å¿ource, the Å¿prigs, the boughs, and fruits;
Of more then thou canÅ¿t heare, or I relate,
That with high hand I Å¿till did perpetrate;
For theÅ¿e, were threatned the wofull day,
I mock'd the Preachers, put it farre away;
The Sermons yet upon record doe Å¿tand,
That cry'd, deÅ¿truction to my wicked Land:
TheÅ¿e Prophets mouthes (al â¢ s the while) was Å¿topt,
Unworthily, Å¿ome backs whipt, and eares crept;
Their reverent checks, did beare the glorious markes
Of Å¿tinking, Å¿tigmatizing, RomiÅ¿h Clerkes;
Some loÅ¿t their livings, Å¿ome in priÅ¿on pent,
Some groÅ¿Å¿ely fin'd, from friends to exile went:
Their Å¿ilent tongues to heaven did vengeance cry,
Who heard their cauÅ¿e, and wrongs judg'd righteouÅ¿ly,
And will repay it Å¿evenfold in my lap,
This is fore-runner of my after clap,
Not took I warning by my neighbours falls,

lg.l: To all you've Å¿aid, Å¿ad mother, I aÅ¿Å¿ent

div.head: An Elegie upon that Honourable and renowned Knight, Sir Philip Sidney, who was untimely Å¿laine at the Seige of Zutphon, Anno 1586.
By A. B. in the yeare, 1638.

lg.l: WHen England did injoy her HalÅ¿ion dayes,

No leÅ¿Å¿e an Honour to our BritiÅ¿h Land,

Calliope with TerpÅ¿echer did Å¿ing,
Of PoeÅ¿ie, and of MuÅ¿ick thou wert King;
Thy Rhethorick it Å¿truck Polimnia dead,
Thine Eloquence made Mercury wax red;
Thy Logick from Euterpe won the Crown,
More worth was thine, then Clio could Å¿et down.
Thalia, and Melpomene, Å¿ay th' truth,
(WitneÅ¿Å¿e Arcadia, penn'd in his youth)
Are not his Tragick Comedies Å¿o acted,
As if your nine-fold wit had been compacted;
To Å¿hew the wo ld, they never Å¿aw before,
That this one Volumne Å¿hould exhauÅ¿t your Å¿tore.
I praiÅ¿e thee not for this, it is unfit,
This was thy Å¿hame, O miracle of wit:
Yet doth thy Å¿hame (with all) purchaÅ¿e renown,
What doe thy vertues then? Oh, honours crown!
In all records, thy Name I ever Å¿ee,

Let then, none diÅ¿-allow of theÅ¿e my Å¿traines,
Which have the Å¿elf-Å¿ame blood yet in my veines;

Thy wiÅ¿er dayes, condemn'd thy witty works,

But Å¿ome infatuate fooles Å¿oone caught therein,
Found Cupids Dam, had never Å¿uch a Gin;
Which makes Å¿everer eyes but Å¿corn thy Story,
Yet, he's a beetle head, that cann't diÅ¿cry
A world of treaÅ¿ure, in that rubbiÅ¿h lye;
And doth thy Å¿elfe, thy worke, and honour wrong,
(O brave Refiner of our B â¢ iuiÅ¿h Tongue;)
That Å¿ees not learning, valour, and morality,
JuÅ¿tice, friendÅ¿hip, and kind hoÅ¿pitality;

Such were prejudicate, and did not look:

Thy fame, and praiÅ¿e, is farre beyond my Å¿traine;
Yet great AuguÅ¿tus was content (we know)
To be Å¿aluted by a Å¿illy Crow;

A Crow's a Crow, and CaeÅ¿ar is a King.
O brave Achilles, I wiÅ¿h Å¿ome Homer would
Engrave on Marble, in characters of Gold,
What famous feats thou didÅ¿t, on Flanders coaÅ¿t,
Of which, this day, faire Belgia doth boaÅ¿t.
O Zutphon, Zutphon, that moÅ¿t fatall City,
Made famous by thy fall, much more's the pitty;
Ah, in his blooming prime, death pluckt this RoÅ¿e,
E're he was ripe; his thred cut Atropos.
Thus man is borne to dye, and dead is he,
Brave Hector by the walls of Troy, we Å¿ee:
Oh, who was neare thee, but did Å¿ore repine;
He reÅ¿cued not with life, that life of thine,
But yet impartiall Death this Boone did give,
Though Sidney dy'd, his valiant name Å¿hould live;
And live it doth, in Å¿pight of death, through fame,
Thus being over-come, he over-came.
Where is that envious tongue, but can afford,
Of this our noble Scipio Å¿ome good word?
Noble Bartas, this to thy praiÅ¿e adds more,
In Å¿ad, Å¿weet verÅ¿e, thou didÅ¿t his death deplore;
IlluÅ¿trious Stella, thou didÅ¿t thine full well,
If thine aÅ¿pect was milde to AÅ¿trophell;
I feare thou wert a Commet, did portend
Such prince as he, his race Å¿hould Å¿hortly end:
If Å¿uch Stars as theÅ¿e, Å¿ad preÅ¿ages be,
I wiÅ¿h no more Å¿uch Blazers we may Å¿ee;
But thou art gone, Å¿uch Meteors never laÅ¿t,
And as thy beauty, Å¿o thy name would waÅ¿t,
But that it is record by Philips hand,
That Å¿uch an omen once was in our land,
O Princely Philip, rather Alexander,
Who wert of honours band, the chief Commander.
How could that Stella, Å¿o confine thy will?
To wait till Å¿he, her influence diÅ¿till,
I rather judg'd thee of his mind that wept,
To be within the bounds of one world kept,
But Omphala, Å¿et Hercules to Å¿pin,
And Mars himÅ¿elf was ta'n by Venus gin;
Then wonder leÅ¿Å¿e, if warlike Philip yield,
When Å¿uch a Hero Å¿hoots him out o'th' field,
Yet this preheminence thou haÅ¿t above,
That thine was true, but theirs adult'rate love.
Fain would I Å¿hew, how thou fame's path didÅ¿t tread,
But now into Å¿uch Lab'rinths am I led
With end leÅ¿Å¿e turnes, the way I find not out,
For to perÅ¿iÅ¿t, my muÅ¿e is more in doubt:
Calls me ambitious fool, that durÅ¿t aÅ¿pire,
Enough for me to look, and Å¿o admire.
And makes me now with SylveÅ¿ter confeÅ¿Å¿e,
But Sydney's MuÅ¿e, can Å¿ing his worthineÅ¿Å¿e.
Too late my errour Å¿ee, that durÅ¿t preÅ¿ume
To fix my faltring lines upon his tomb:
Which are in worth, as far Å¿hort of his due,
As Vulcan is, of Venus native hue.
Goodwill, did make my head-long pen to run,
Like unwiÅ¿e Phaeton his ill guided Å¿onne,
Till taught to's coÅ¿t, for his too haÅ¿ty hand,
He left that charge by Phoebus to be man'd:
So proudly fooliÅ¿h I, with Phaeton Å¿trive,
Fame's flaming Chariot for to drive.
Till terrour-Å¿truck for my too weighty charge.
I leave't in brief, Apollo do't at large.
Apollo laught to patch up what's begun,
He bad me drive, and he would hold the Sun,
Better my hap, then was his darlings fate,
For dear regard he had of Sydney's Å¿tate,
Who in his Deity, had Å¿o deep Å¿hare,
That thoÅ¿e that name his fame, he needs muÅ¿t Å¿pare,
He Promis'd much, but th' muÅ¿es had no will,
To give to their detractor any quill.
With high diÅ¿dain, they Å¿aid they gave no more,
Since Sydney had exhauÅ¿ted all their Å¿tore,
That this contempt it did the more perplex,
In being done by one of their own Å¿ex;
They took from me, the Å¿cribling pen I had,
I to be eas'd of Å¿uch a task was glad.
For to revenge his wrong, themÅ¿elves ingage,
And drave me from ParnaÅ¿Å¿us in a rage,

I penÅ¿ive for my fault, Å¿at down, and then,
Errata, through their leave threw me my pen,

So Sydney's fame, I leave to England's Rolls,

div.head: In honour of Du Bartas. 1641.

lg.head: A. B.
lg.l: AMongÅ¿t the happy wits this Age hath Å¿howne,
Great, deare, Å¿weet Bartas, thou art marchleÅ¿Å¿e knowne;
My raviÅ¿ht eyes, and heart, with faltering tongue,

My dazled Å¿ight of late, review'd thy lines,
Where Art, and more then Art in Nature Å¿hines;

Which Rayes, datting upon Å¿ome richer ground,

If Summer, or my Au â¢ umne age, doe yeeld
â¢â¢ ewers, Å¿ruits, in garden, orchard, or in Å¿ield;
They Å¿hall be conÅ¿ecrated in my VerÅ¿e,

My MuÅ¿e unto a Childe, I fitly may compare,

But Å¿eeing empty wiÅ¿hes nought obtaine,

And tells her tales; (his full heart over-glad)
Of all the glorious Å¿ights his eyes have had:
But findes too Å¿oone his want of Eloquence,
The Å¿illy Pratler Å¿peakes no word of Å¿ence;
And Å¿eeing utterance fayle his great deÅ¿ires,
Sits down in filence, deeply he admires:
Thus weake brain'd I, reading thy lofty Å¿tile,
Thy profound Learning; viewing other while
Thy Art, in Naturall PhiloÅ¿ophy:
Thy Saint-like minde in grave Divinity,
Thy peircing skill in high AÅ¿tronomy,
And curious in-Å¿ight in Anatomy;
Thy PhiÅ¿ick, MuÅ¿ick, and State policy,
Valour in War, in Peace good Husbandry.
Sure liberall Nature, did with Art not Å¿mall,

A thouÅ¿and thouÅ¿and times my Å¿enÅ¿leÅ¿Å¿e Sences,
MoveleÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿tand charm'd by thy Å¿weet influences,
More Å¿enceleÅ¿Å¿e then the Stones to Amphions Lute,
Mine eyes are Å¿ightleÅ¿Å¿e, and my tongue is mute;

O France, in him thou didÅ¿t more glory gain,

Who tam'd his foes, in bloud, in skarres and Å¿weat,
Thy fame is Å¿pread as farre, I dare be bold,

Thine the quinteÅ¿Å¿ence of an Heroick brain.

Who in thy tryumphs (never won by wrongs)

If e'r this golden gift was Å¿how â¢ 'd on anv,
Thy double portion would have Å¿erved many.
Unto each man his riches are aÅ¿Å¿ign'd,
Of names, of Å¿tate, of body, or of mind,
Thou haÅ¿t thy part of all, but of the laÅ¿t,
Oh pregnant brain, Oh comprehenÅ¿ion vaÅ¿t:
Thy haughty Å¿tile, and rapted wit Å¿ublime,

Thy Å¿acred works are not for imitation,

Thus Bartas fame Å¿hall laÅ¿t while Å¿tarres do Å¿land,

div.head: In honour of that High and Mighty PrinceÅ¿s, Queen ELIZABETH, of moÅ¿t happy memory.

lg.head: The Proem.
lg.l: ALthough great Queen, thou now in Å¿ilence lye,

lg.head: The Poem.
lg.l: NO Phoenix Pen, nor Spencers Poetry,
No Speeds, nor Chamdens learned HiÅ¿tory;
Eliza's works, wars, praiÅ¿e, can e're compact,
The World's the Theater where Å¿he did act;
No memories, nor volumes can containe,
The nine Olimp'ades of her happy reigne;
Who was Å¿o good, Å¿o juÅ¿t, Å¿o learn'd, Å¿o wiÅ¿e,
From all the Kings on earth Å¿he won the prize;
Nor Å¿ay I more then duly is her due,
She hath wip'd off th' aÅ¿perÅ¿ion of her Sex,
Spaines Monarch Å¿a's not Å¿o; nor yet his H â¢â¢ Å¿t,
She taught them better manners to their coÅ¿t.
The Salique Law had not in force now been,

But can you Doctors now this point diÅ¿pute,
She's argument enough to make you mute;
Since firÅ¿t the Sun did run, his ne'r â¢ unn'd race,

Sin â¢ e time was time, and man unmanly man,
Come Å¿hew me Å¿uch a Phoenix if you can;
Was ever people better rul'd then hers?

Did ever wealth in England Å¿o abound?
Her Victories in forraigne CoaÅ¿ts reÅ¿ound?

She ract, Å¿he Å¿ackt, Å¿he Å¿unk his Armadoe;

She frankly help'd Franks (brave) diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed King,

Her Nobles Å¿acriÅ¿ic'd their noble blood,

Had ever Prince Å¿uch CounÅ¿ellors as Å¿he?
Her Å¿elfe Minerva, caus'd them Å¿o to be;
Such Souldiers, and Å¿uch Captaines never Å¿een,
As were the Å¿ubjects of our (Pallas) Queen:

But time would faile me, Å¿o my wit would to,
